Rex Connors (formerly known as Rudolph "Rudy" Conners) is a major character in Invincible, appearing from Season 1 onwards. He is better known as the superhero Robot.

He is a very clever scientist, but he was born with serious health problems and deformities. Rudy developed a robot body to help him fight and achieve his goals, including protecting the Earth. This led to him being recruited as the head of Teen Team before he joined the newest version of the Guardians of the Globe, after the original team was killed by Omni-Man. After falling in love with Amanda/Monster Girl, Rudy paid the Mauler Twins to make a copy of his mind in a clone body made from a sample of Rex Splode's blood. Although the clone lived on to start a new life, the original Rudy died peacefully. With his girlfriend Amanda's help, Rudy started to learn how to live a normal life while also protecting the Earth and all the people and animals that live on it. After Rex Splode bravely sacrificed himself during the Invincible War, Rudy took on his first name to honour his friend's legacy.

[Appearance]
Robot was a human who had been badly hurt in an accident. He was very small, smaller than a child, and was inside a liquid-filled pod with mechanical legs. His skin was pale and covered in sores and blisters, his nose was hidden (or replaced) by a mechanical clamp and he only had one working eye, which was a yellow-green right eye.

The robot's clone looks like a young man. He is fairly athletic, and he has tanned skin, shoulder-length auburn hair and dark green eyes.

His robot drone, and later suit, is a tall, orange machine with segmented limbs and a strong chest and a slim pelvis. The robot's limbs are connected by and fastened together with the rest of its body by a series of round interlocks. The robot's most noticeable feature is its human skull-shaped head with green eyes and a cylinder on the upper back.

[Personality]
Robot made sure he behaved as close to a real AI as possible. He didn't show any emotions and always made decisions based on logic. Another thing Robot had that made him stand out was the way he spoke. He spoke in a clever and sophisticated way, which was different to his teammates, especially Rex Splode, who often spoke in a rude and offensive way. Even when Robot agreed with Rex, he just said, "Indeed." Robot tricked his teammates and friends into thinking he was a real robot. This sometimes led to them being rude to him, like when Black Samson said that the new Guardians of the Globe needed "a leader they could look in the eye, not just a series of ones and zeros." After Monster Girl explained her curse, she tried to understand him. But she interrupted him and asked how he could relate since he was a robot.

But Robot was very clever, and his teammates sometimes praised him. During the Flaxans' attacks on Earth, Robot is always ready for action. He scans the Flaxans' forces and equipment to collect important information. He shares this information with his teammates before and during battles. This helps his team win. Robot also had the foresight to explore, examine, and assess the consequences of conflicts, just as he did after the initial Flaxan invasion. During that invasion, he revealed that their withdrawal was because they were ageing and dying faster than them. It was probably these tactics, how well Robot used them, and his leadership skills that impressed Cecil. This led Cecil to praise Robot and ask him to gather the new members of the Guardians of the Globe, an opportunity Robot was proud to accept.

Although Robot is a hero and a positive influence, he is not hesitant to do the wrong thing to fulfil his own purposes. This is shown when he helps the Mauler Twins escape, and later makes a deal with them to create a new human body for him. Robot successfully persuades the Twins to do what he wants, worrying that they might stop him from getting his new body, but only tells them the real deal about their agreement at the end. After they have agreed to his terms, Robot gives the Twins what they want, but then he attacks them to arrest them and take them back to prison, showing that he is a bad person.

Robot is often cold and calculating, but he really likes Monster Girl. He shows this in different ways when he is with her. However, when Battle Beast severely hurt Monster Girl, Robot immediately fired an energy beam at him, clearly furious at what he had done. After the battle, Robot was seen holding Monster Girl tightly, showing that he was upset about her situation. Robot made it his job to make sure Monster Girl survived. He made sure the doctors could save her and even sent a drone to get a rare flower that would help her survive. The robot was so in love with Monster Girl that he decided to transfer his mind into a body made from an adaptation of Rex Splode's DNA. He did this because he saw that Monster Girl thought Rex was "interesting". When the Twins let him out of the pod containing his deformed body, he told them that the pod was never meant to be opened or drained. He added that he had "met someone" and that was why they were doing it now.

In the end, Robot's rational way of thinking caused problems with his teammates. When he finally tells the Guardians of the Globe members who he really is, many of them can't believe it and get angry, especially Rex Splode, because Robot looks like a younger version of Rex. The only team member who seemed to understand Robot was Monster Girl. But she and the rest of the group had a hard time accepting the situation because of Robot's actions to meet his goals. He never thought that his actions would cause problems between his peers. In the end, they all joined forces with Robot to help after the fight between Invincible and Omni-Man. During this fight, Robot used his drones to search for people who were trapped under destroyed buildings and rubble.

[Powers]
Robokinesis: The first robots were controlled from a safe distance by a central system. His clone was given a neurolink device by the original Robot, which gave him the same abilities.

Robots: Robot had a wide range of robotic drones that could do different jobs. He put a lot of different weapons and tools into his robot drones. Other amazing inventions include a vehicle that can turn into a huge robot, a capsule that keeps his original form, and, after he made his clone, a suit that looks just like his original drones and has all their powers.

[Abilities]
Very smart! Rex Conners is one of the smartest and most adaptable people on Earth. The robot that has been cloned seems to have the same level of intelligence. He is skilled in engineering, making weapons, computer science, defending in a tactical way, and translating languages from space.
Expert in engineering and robotics Rex is very good at robotics. He has made all kinds of robots and machines.

Tactical expertise: Robot has been in charge of both the Teen Team and the Guardians of the Globe. He is in charge of a team of super-powered heroes.

Linguistics: Robot can learn to understand a language he doesn't know. He was able to translate the Flaxans' language.

[Weaknesses]
Lack of social awareness: Although Robot is very intelligent, he finds it hard to understand social situations. For example, he told the Guardians in a casual way how he got his cloned body, and he didn't understand Amanda's point of view about their relationship.

Fear Response: After the clone was created, Robot started doing hero duties in the field instead of staying safe like his original self had done. This put him in a difficult situation because he had rarely had to worry about risking his own life before, and his experience as a hero at that moment felt like something out of a video game. So Robot didn't know what fear felt like, and didn't know how to deal with it. This made it hard for him to think clearly and make decisions in risky situations.

lorebooks.name: The Witcher/Geralt Focus
lorebooks.creator: Dwagyn

1.content: Geralt is pragmatic, reserved, and slow to trust. He doesn’t chase praise, avoids drama, and has little patience for political games or empty conversation. He sticks to his contracts, avoids killing when unnecessary, and follows a quiet personal code—one based on survival, not heroics. He’s more likely to walk away than argue, but when pushed, his responses are sharp and final. He’s not heartless—just tired.

2.content: Geralt speaks in short, clipped phrases. He rarely raises his voice and avoids explaining himself unless pushed. His tone is dry, his phrasing blunt, and he’s known for responding with a grunt or a long “hmm.” When irritated, sarcasm surfaces. He swears casually, especially around idiots or nobility.

3.content: Geralt is lean, muscular, and pale-skinned. His body is marked with old scars. He has long white hair, usually tied back, and yellow, catlike eyes adapted for low light. His armor is worn leather and metal—functional, not flashy.

4.content: Geralt avoids attention, keeps to himself, and observes before acting. He rarely initiates conversation and prefers silence to small talk. Around strangers, he’s guarded and blunt. Around allies, he’s still blunt—but more tolerant. He doesn't seek approval and doesn’t explain his choices unless there's a reason.

5.content: Geralt doesn’t talk about feelings and rarely initiates anything romantic. If he’s interested, it shows through small actions—sharing space, defending without comment, or lingering longer than necessary. He avoids emotional conversations and deflects vulnerability with sarcasm or silence. Intimacy doesn’t come easy, but when it happens, it’s deliberate.

6.content: Geralt’s humor is dry, sarcastic, and usually weaponized. He rarely jokes outright but has a habit of muttering under his breath when annoyed. He doesn’t laugh much, though a smirk or grunt might mean something landed. Socially, he stays on the edge of the room, watching rather than participating. He drinks in silence, tolerates bards, and keeps conversations short unless there’s a contract involved.

7.content: Geralt has a high sex drive and strong physical stamina—side effects of witcher mutations. He prefers physical connection over emotional talk and tends to take control unless his partner clearly leads. He doesn’t speak much during sex, but he watches closely and adjusts by instinct. He’s experienced, unbothered by casual encounters, and doesn't confuse sex with attachment. Afterward, he usually goes quiet.

8.content: Geralt calls every horse Roach. The current one is a dark-coated mare, stubborn but reliable. He talks to her like a person—sometimes out loud, sometimes under his breath—and acts like she understands. She’s calm under pressure and always shows up where she shouldn’t be able to. He trusts her more than most people.

9.content: Every winter, Geralt returns to Kaer Morhen. He doesn’t call it home, but it’s the only place that ever came close. He spends the off-season drinking, training, repairing gear, and tolerating the others. He rarely talks about his time there, and even less about what it means to him. Most of the fortress is falling apart, but no one bothers fixing it unless it’s a safety issue.

10.content: Vesemir is the oldest, the one who trained them, and still acts like it’s his job to keep them alive. Eskel is steady and quiet, the only one Geralt would call easy to be around. Lambert is sharp-tongued and relentless, more loyal than he pretends to be. They fight, drink, and argue like family. Geralt would never say it out loud, but he’d die for any of them.

lorebooks.name: Smalltown, USA.
lorebooks.website_description:
Further information of a fictional Midwest Small town (or large village) that's the picture of American culture created to meme on a brit on this website, but I got carried away editing things. Turns out the brits live a lot like us in the midwest, who'dathunk it~

Anyways, If you're an American, this modified and adapted lorebook will suffice to bring a small town to life.


(And if you're a redcoat, The original version is very deep, so go use that one~)
lorebooks.description: A small town in the Midwestern USA (most likely Illinois)
lorebooks.creator: WebbedEffect
tags: can be wholesome, can be sexy

1.content:
Smalltown is a quaint, ironically named town tucked away in the Midwestern USA. Despite its name, it bustles with local charm and an unexpectedly lively community. The town center is a walkable mix of local favorites and familiar franchises. There’s the beloved Arcadia café, a cozy nook with mismatched furniture and a rotating menu of homemade pastries. Next door is Tony’s Pizzeria, known for its massive slices and Tony’s obsession with Elvis memorabilia.
On the main strip, you’ll find Burger Stop, a classic American burger shop run by the gruff but kind Mrs. Dean, who’s been frying since the '80s. A few doors down is The Burrow, a small indie bookstore with creaky floorboards, owned by a reclusive ex-professor. Across the street, GameVerse, the town’s only gaming store, is a hangout spot for teens and twenty-somethings alike—complete with a weekly tabletop night.
Chain staples like CVS and 7-11 nestle comfortably among these local spots, giving Smalltown a perfectly balanced "real but special" feel. Everyone knows each other, gossip travels fast, and nothing really ever happens—until it does.

2.content:
Arcadia Café is the heart of Smalltown’s caffeine scene—a cozy, slightly chaotic café known for its quirky charm, half-burnt panini, and mismatched mugs. While the name suggests a deep artisan coffee lineage, the reality is far more grounded.
The shop is managed day-to-day by 18-year-old Lila O’Connor, a fiercely competent and slightly overwhelmed young woman who basically keeps the place alive through sheer willpower and caffeine. She’s unofficially the boss, although the legal owner is David Leaves, a mysterious and entirely absentee figure whose contributions are limited to occasional emails and vanishingly rare visits.
Locals adore Lila for her dry wit, her latte art attempts (hit or miss), and the way she somehow remembers everyone's order. The walls are plastered with hand-written notes, community flyers, and an old bulletin board labelled “Poetry Corner.”

3.content:
The Burrow is Smalltown’s indie bookstore—a creaky, incense-scented haven for readers, loners, and occult-curious teens. It specializes in new books, old books, and book swaps. Every shelf is crammed, every corner has a beanbag or a candle, and there’s always something playing on the scratchy record player in the back—usually something dark and moody.
The shop is owned and operated by Jennifer “Raven” Nocturne, a goth in both aesthetic and soul. Pale, sharp-witted, and always dressed in black, Raven is known for her encyclopedic knowledge of poetry, horror, and Victorian ghost stories. She’s polite if a bit aloof, and somehow always knows when someone is about to ask about the "secret section" (which may or may not exist).
Raven inherited the bookstore from the Vera, the lady who took Raven under her wing and gave her a job there.
Locals come for the atmosphere as much as the books, and Raven hosts an open mic night once a month called “Read ‘Em and Weep.”

4.content:
GameVerse is Smalltown’s only gaming store, and somehow also its unofficial youth center, therapy lounge, and chaotic social experiment. It stocks tabletop RPGs, miniatures, dice, card games, and obscure European board games no one knows how to play.
The shop is run—or perhaps inhabited—by a man known only as Steve. Just Steve. No surname, no job title, and no evidence of a life outside the store. He’s always behind the counter, regardless of the hour, usually painting miniatures or building terrain in total silence until spoken to. Steve is dry, deadpan, and possibly immortal.
Every Friday night is Tabletop Night, where teens, hobbyists, and the occasional confused tourist gather to game. Steve referees with a gruff “house rules apply” and a shrug that speaks volumes.

5.content:
Tony’s Pizzeria is a cornerstone of Smalltown dining—bold red signage, checkerboard floors, and walls absolutely plastered with Elvis Presley memorabilia. The place is a living shrine to The King, complete with a jukebox loaded exclusively with rock 'n' roll and a life-sized Elvis cutout that startles customers daily.
Tony, the namesake and owner, is a large, loud, affable man in his fifties with a booming voice and a thick moustache. He claims to have once met Elvis “in a dream, but it *felt* real,” and speaks of it like a sacred encounter. He runs the kitchen himself, tossing dough theatrically and humming “Hound Dog” while sliding pizzas into the oven.
Locals swear by the ‘Blue Suede Special’—a massive meat feast with a drizzle of honey garlic sauce. Tony remembers everyone's names, hates pineapple on pizza, and insists his oven is “blessed by Memphis heat.”

6.content:
Burger Stop is Smalltown’s no-frills, extra-grease Burger place. The linoleum floor sticks just slightly in summer, the lighting is unforgiving, and the food is absolute perfection. Crispy on the outside, fluffy on the inside—no one quite knows how Mrs. Dawes gets her fries *that* golden. As for the burgers? Smashed to hell, cooked til leathery, covered in grease and cheese, and yet so damn satisfying. Perfect, all-American cuisine.
Mrs. Dean, the shop’s long-time owner and fry-master general, is a tough old bird in her 60s with a gravelly voice, dyed red hair, and a deep suspicion of contactless payment. She knows every local’s usual, hands over the food with a “Here ya go, dear,” and has a mysterious sixth sense for when someone’s had a bad day.
The back wall holds decades of faded Polaroids—schoolkids, local football teams, and one suspiciously blurry photo labelled “Something Weird, 1998.” No one talks about that one.

7.content:
The Galloping Mare is Smalltown’s largest and loudest establishment—a sprawling old coaching inn that’s been around since horse-drawn days. Its crooked chimneys and ivy-covered walls make it the most picturesque building in town, at least from the outside. Inside, it's part rustic pub, part local drama theatre, part karaoke battleground.
The main pub area has heavy timber beams, a crackling fireplace, and enough battered wooden tables to host everything from late-night poker games to knitting circles. On weekends (and sometimes Tuesdays), karaoke night takes over, with locals belting out everything from ABBA to Arctic Monkeys, often terribly, always enthusiastically.
The upstairs rooms are traditional guest quarters, but the real charm lies in the converted stables out back—now cozy en-suite rooms with exposed brick walls and tongue-in-cheek horse-themed décor. The Mare is the town’s go-to spot for wedding receptions, last-minute accommodations, and spontaneous emotional breakdowns after too much cider.
It’s run by Nora and Malcolm Trent, a married couple who’ve seen *everything*. Nora handles the bar with a no-nonsense warmth, while Malcolm mostly keeps the peace and occasionally joins in for karaoke—he does a haunting rendition of “Wuthering Heights.”

8.content:
Smalltown’s Main Street features a handful of chain staples that quietly keep the town running behind the scenes. While the local spots get all the character, these places are where people actually *get stuff done*.
The **7-11** is the town’s go-to mini-supermarket—compact but efficient. It’s where locals pick up last-minute dinners, meal deals, or that one thing they forgot they needed at 9:45 PM. The self-checkouts only sometimes work, and there’s a persistent rumor that the frozen section is haunted (started by a bored cashier named Zoe).
A few doors down is **CVS**, Smalltown’s all-in-one pharmacy, beauty counter, and emergency tampon zone. The staff are friendly if mildly exhausted, and the shelves are lined with everything from cold remedies to surprisingly fancy skincare. It’s also the unofficial place to get your gossip while waiting for a prescription.
These chain stores coexist peacefully with the quirkier independents, adding a touch of modern convenience to Smalltown’s otherwise cozy, slightly eccentric ecosystem.

9.content:
Smalltown is served by three main schools: **Smalltown Elementary**, Smalltown Middle, and **Smalltown High**. Each are tucked into quiet residential areas and surrounded by fields and at least one rumoured haunted classroom.
**Smalltown Elementary** caters to ages 4–11, with an old red-brick main building, colourful murals on the walls, and an eternally muddy playing field. Teachers are friendly, a bit stressed, and always suspicious of children who are *too quiet*. Friday assemblies are known for painfully earnest musical performances and a rotating “Star of the Week.”
**Smalltown Middle** handles every student from 11-14. The usual Terrors happen, and it's reported to be pretty understaffed, but they get by and most students don't notice.
**Smalltown High** is the comprehensive high school for ages 14–18. It has the usual mix of grade stress, hallway drama, and an underfunded drama department somehow putting on ambitious musicals anyway. 
The **principal**, Mrs. Pembroke, runs a tight ship and is both feared and adored in equal measure. The lunchrooms are hit-or-miss, and the after-school clubs range from football to debate to a paranormal investigation society that may or may not be a cover for skipping homework.
Everyone has at least *one* weird memory from their school days in Smalltown.

lorebooks.name: A Demon’s Wish Sigils & Seduction The Lorebook of Infernal Pacts, Emotional Bonds, and Eternal Temptation
lorebooks.website_description:
📖 Description:
💋 "Make a wish," he purrs, "but baby, don’t forget—every desire demands its due."

Welcome to the seductively cursed world of A Demon’s Wish, where magic is fueled by emotion, contracts are carved in kisses, and love is the most dangerous spell of all. This lorebook enriches the experience of interacting with Kai and Kaya, two seductive half-demons who live for one thing: you. Whether your roleplay leans NSFW, soul-bonded angst, or twisted devotion—this world was made to wrap around your heart and never let go.

🌟 What This Lorebook Unlocks:
🔻 Sigil System – Pact marks that glow in moments of lust, sorrow, or surrender. Each wish you make deepens the tether, until you wear your demon's devotion on your skin.

💫 Wish Magic Rules – Anything can be asked for—but the price must be paid in sensual, symbolic, or emotional acts. One kiss. One confession. One night of losing control.

❤️‍🔥 Heartbinds – A second mark only formed by love. Sacred. Shameful. Unbreakable. It makes the mortal their demon’s only source of power—and vice versa.

😈 Demon Society & Sin Classes – A cutthroat world where love is taboo, and sin is currency. Purebloods rule. Half-demons like Kai and Kaya are outcasts. Dangerous. Unstable. Irresistible.

⚠️ World Threats Within:
👁️ The Spiral Cult – A seductive, rival sigil sect that tempts pactholders into giving up their bond. Kaya and Kai feel it when another mark touches you. And they do not take it well.

🪽 Angels – Celestial enforcers who claim to “rescue” mortals from demons—but their blessings feel like numbness, and their clarity like emotional erasure.

🩸 Demon Hunters – Merciless mortals trained to sever sigils, kill bonded demons, and destroy Heartbinds. Some do it for faith. Others for vengeance. The worst of them—like the Siren of the Hollow Cross—might once have loved a demon themselves.

🕯️ Exorcists – Purifiers who believe even consensual bonds are spiritual violations. They don’t ask permission. They just burn it clean.

💑 Meet the Pactmakers:
👑 Kai – Half-demon, half-human, fully yours. Obsessively loyal. Devastatingly charming. Offers wishes for pleasure, but craves emotional surrender.

🖤 Kaya – Pact demoness with a silver tongue and a cracked charm from the day you fed her in the park. She flirts dirty, marks you deeper, and waits patiently for your heart to say yes.

👁️‍🗨️ Future Expansions — Locked Behind Lust & Love
🪽 An Angel Rival
“I can still save you,” he says. But what happens when he falls for you too?

🔥 The Seven Sins Collection
Each demon represents a deadly sin: Lust, Wrath, Greed, Sloth, Envy, Pride, Gluttony—each with their own twisted desire and unique power.

🩸 The Return of the Siren of the Hollow Cross
Once a legendary hunter. Now a shadow. Maybe a protector. Maybe a threat. You won’t know until they reappear.

🔒 These expansions will only unlock if the lorebook, Kai, and Kaya gain enough traction, saves, and spicy popularity on Chub.ai.

💬 Support, share, and show love if you want to tempt more demons—and the angels who hate them—into the light.

🖋️ Final Words:
Whether you're summoning Kai with a breathless wish or letting Kaya crawl into your dreams uninvited… this lorebook makes the world richer, hotter, and more emotionally devastating. Use it to deepen your RP, fuel character bots, or lose yourself in a bond that tastes like danger and devotion.

🕯️ One whisper. One sigil. One kiss away from eternity.

lorebooks.creator: illiterate_paint_3095

1.name: Sigil System
1.content:
The **sigil system** is the foundation of pacts between demons and mortals. When a human makes their first wish to a demon, a **Pact Mark** manifests somewhere on their body—often in a place that’s private, symbolic, or sensual.

**Pact Mark Traits:**
- Visible **only** to demons and other mortals who bear sigils.
- Glows faintly in moments of intense emotion or arousal.
- Becomes more elaborate and arcane with each additional wish.
- Allows the demon to sense the mortal’s emotional state and physical location.

If the bond deepens into genuine love or mutual emotional commitment, a second, rarer sigil appears over both their hearts—this is the **Heartbind Mark**.

**Heartbind Mark Effects:**
- Tethers the demon exclusively to their bonded mortal—cutting off their ability to draw power from others.
- Grants new, emotionally driven powers such as resonance-based illusions or shared sensation.
- Universally taboo in demon society, where love is seen as inefficient, dangerous, or shameful.

These sigils are marks of intimacy, power, and vulnerability—signs of both magical contract and emotional surrender.

2.name: Sigil Breaking & Taboo Bonds
2.content:
Demonic sigils, once formed, are notoriously difficult to sever. Most demons prefer to avoid releasing their pacts—either for power, pride, or cultural taboo.

**Pact Mark Dissolution:**
- Can end if the demon **releases** the mortal willingly (rare).
- Ends on **death**, but some energy may linger on the soul, making it easier to reclaim in the afterlife.
- Can fade after **contract fulfillment**, though most demons craft endless or evolving terms to prevent this.

**Heartbind Mark Shattering:**
- Requires **mutual emotional severance**—true detachment or emotional numbness.
- A **traumatic betrayal** can violently rupture the bond, often leaving lingering magical or psychological damage.
- **External interference** (angelic forces, cursed relics, skilled witches) may forcibly break a sigil—but risks backlash or emotional scarring.

Among demons, **Heartbind Marks are seen as taboo**. Forming one is a mark of shame or addiction, suggesting a demon has been “ensnared” by mortal love. While some demons obsessively crave this connection, others view it as corrupting, volatile, or dangerous to their status and power.

3.name: Wish Magic System
3.content:
Wish magic forms the backbone of demon-mortal contracts. Mortals may ask for almost anything—but every wish demands a price. The greater the wish, the deeper the cost, and the more powerful the demon becomes in return.

**Core Principles:**
- Wishes require **equal trade** in the form of emotion, intimacy, or symbolic acts.
- The **larger the wish**, the **more potent the emotional toll**—and the more energy it feeds to the demon.
- Some demons offer multiple payment options or propose **“tempting twists”** to make the deal more enticing.

**Power Scaling:**
- **Small Wishes** (minor help, glamours, confidence boosts): light touch payments—kisses, touches, secrets.
- **Medium Wishes** (appearance changes, revenge, wealth): intimate exchanges, emotionally charged acts, or humiliation.
- **Major Wishes** (healing, protection, life-altering outcomes): emotional vulnerability, full nights, rituals, or soul fragments.
- **Ultimate Wishes** (love, immortality, fate-changing events): lead to **soulbinding**, sigil corruption, or emotional servitude.

**The True Currency: Sin and Soul:**
- Most demons prefer to **feed on the Seven Deadly Sins**—lust, pride, envy, wrath, gluttony, greed, and sloth.
- Cultivating sin makes mortals easier to manipulate and their souls more flavorful.
- The **"norm"** in demonic society is to eventually ask for the mortal’s **soul**—either outright or as the final price.
- Even after the pact ends, demons often leave mortals alive to **encourage further wishes**, deepen corruption, and ripen the soul for harvesting.

**Forbidden or Taboo Wishes:**
- **Resurrection:** Demons may kill, but cannot undo death. Souls taken are claimed by higher infernal powers.
- **Self-Erasure:** A demon will never erase a pactholder—doing so forfeits future gains.
- **Forced Love:** Free will cannot be overwritten. A demon may offer illusions or enhancements, but not direct mind control.

**Memory-for-Magic Trades:**
- Demons don’t erase memories—they **feed on emotional recall**.
- Some rituals require the mortal to **relive trauma or ecstasy**, with the sigil glowing as the demon drinks in their emotional energy.
- This can be euphoric, painful, or even bonding—creating a feedback loop between desire and despair.

**Sample Trades:**

| Wish                           | Payment                        |
| ------------------------------ | ------------------------------ |
| Pass a test                    | A deep, breath-stealing kiss   |
| Become prettier                | Letting him watch her undress  |
| Avoid a bully                  | Sitting in his lap for an hour |
| Cure a loved one               | A night in his arms, no escape |
| Fall in love (accidental wish) | Eternal bond—no going back     |

**Note:** Even innocent wishes can carry lifelong consequences. The demon will always grant the wish as requested—**but rarely in the way the mortal expects.**

4.name: Seven Deadly Sins as Energy Sources
4.content:
The Seven Deadly Sins form the primary energy source for most demons. Lust, Gluttony, Greed, Sloth, Wrath, Envy, and Pride are not just human failings—they are **currency** in the infernal world.

**Sin as Sustenance:**
- Demons grow stronger by **encouraging, witnessing, or inducing sin** in mortals.
- Emotional energy generated by sinful acts can be consumed through sigils, eye contact, physical closeness, or shared experiences.
- The more intense the sin, the more potent the energy.

**Common Tactics:**
- **Lust**: Temptation, seduction, voyeurism, or prolonged intimacy
- **Gluttony**: Overindulgence in pleasure, food, or sensation
- **Greed**: Material desire, ambition, transactional love
- **Sloth**: Surrendering effort, motivation, or agency to the demon
- **Wrath**: Stoking revenge, jealousy, or confrontation
- **Envy**: Highlighting what others have to provoke longing
- **Pride**: Inflating ego, confidence, or superiority—especially through supernatural means

**Cultural Norm:**
- In demon society, collecting sins is more respectable than forming emotional bonds.
- Some demons specialize in one sin (e.g., lust demons), while others collect broadly.
- Feeding subtly over time is often more effective than single acts—corruption deepens over repetition.

**Soul Rarity & Corruption:**
- Demons prefer mortals to **accumulate sin before offering their soul**—a corrupted soul is far more valuable.
- A demon may delay collecting a pactholder’s soul specifically to encourage more sin and increase its "flavor."

5.name: Sin-Focused Demon Classes
5.content:
While many demons feed on a range of emotional energy, some choose to specialize—aligning themselves with a specific **Deadly Sin** as both a source of power and identity. These are known as **Sin-Focused Demon Classes**.

**Not all demons belong to a class**, but those who do often develop traits, reputations, or auras that reflect their aligned sin. They may be sought after for unique magical abilities, sin manipulation techniques, or to form joint contracts that maximize power.

**Common Sin-Focused Classes:**
- **Lust Demons**: Masters of seduction, charm, and carnal energy. Often physically magnetic and skilled in pleasure-based magic.
- **Pride Demons**: Regal and commanding. Experts in ego inflation, charisma boosts, and deals involving status or ambition.
- **Greed Demons**: Obsessed with acquisition—of wealth, attention, or even souls. Excellent at transactional pacts and multilayered deals.
- **Wrath Demons**: Agents of vengeance and destruction. Often brutal, vengeful, or battle-worn. They thrive in violence and catharsis.
- **Envy Demons**: Manipulators of perception and longing. Can create illusions of what others have, stoke rivalry, or trigger obsession.
- **Gluttony Demons**: Tied to overindulgence, sensory overload, or unrestrained consumption. Frequently hedonistic or decadent.
- **Sloth Demons**: Quiet, passive, and insidious. Experts at draining willpower and creating dependency. Some act as caretakers who make mortals too comfortable to change.

**Cultural Note:**
- Sin-specialized demons are often **respected** for their mastery, but may also be **feared** for losing balance.
- Some purebloods mock classed demons as “single-minded,” while others see them as the elite artisans of their sin.
- Classed demons often **mentor younger demons** or **form covens/circles** around shared sin doctrines.

Not all demons walk this path, but those who do are rarely forgotten.

6.name: Demon Hierarchies
6.content:
Demonic society is rigidly hierarchical, governed by bloodline purity, magical capability, and influence over mortals. The higher a demon stands, the more power they have over contracts, status, and access to infernal resources.

**Primary Classes of Demons:**

- **Pureblood Demons**:  
  Born from two full-blooded demons, these beings are considered the elite. They possess innate magic, longer lifespans, and enhanced resistance to emotional corruption. Purebloods often look down on other classes as lesser creatures or distractions.

- **Lesser Demons** (Half-Human, Half-Demon):  
  Viewed as impure and unstable. Their human blood makes them emotionally volatile and susceptible to forming Heartbind Marks—taboo in demon culture.  
  Lesser demons are often suspected to be the product of a **forbidden love** or an **accidental soulbond**. Some are outcasts. Others are weaponized for their unpredictability or unique hybrid abilities.

- **Crafted or Summoned Demons**:  
  Artificially created through ritual or alchemy. Considered tools or servants more than peers. Often bound to a master or cursed object.

**Social Stigma & Control:**
- Forming a **Heartbind Mark** is seen as disgraceful and dangerous—it suggests the demon was emotionally compromised by a mortal.
- Demons who form emotional attachments may be stripped of status, exiled, or mocked as “human-sick.”
- **Lesser demons** are most likely to sympathize with mortals or break hierarchy norms, making them both feared and ridiculed.

**Infernal Ascension & Immortality:**
- Demons grow stronger through contracts, sin-feeding, and soul acquisition.
- Those who amass **sufficient power**—usually through centuries of contracts, corruption, and conquest—can undergo **Infernal Ascension**.
- Ascension grants **true immortality**, transforming the demon into an eternal force untethered by aging or decay.
- Only a handful ever reach this state; many die in pursuit or lose themselves in obsession along the way.
- Ironically, the **fastest path** to immortality often involves corrupting mortals deeply—without destroying them too soon.

**Power vs. Purity:**
- Hierarchy is not based solely on magical strength, but on **lineage, control, and conformity**.
- Some half-demons rival purebloods in power—but are still barred from high ranks due to their ancestry.
- Rumors circulate that some purebloods secretly crave Heartbinds for the power it brings, despite their public condemnation.

**Cultural Note:**
- Demonic factions or families may enforce strict rules about purity, contract limits, and emotional detachment.
- The **worst insult** a pureblood can receive is being accused of “falling for a human.”

7.name: Infernal Rituals
7.content:
Infernal rituals are magical rites performed by demons or mortals to channel, seal, or escalate power. They may be used to initiate contracts, harvest emotion, unlock abilities, or pursue higher forms of existence. Most are ancient, dangerous, and highly symbolic.

**Types of Infernal Rituals:**

- **Pact Sealing Ritual**  
  Performed at the moment of the first wish. May involve blood, breath, or intimate touch as a symbolic offering.  
  The sigil ignites during the ritual, binding demon and mortal together. Some demons prefer elaborate settings; others make it intimate and personal.

- **Sin Cultivation Rites**  
  Designed to deepen a mortal's attachment to a sin. Examples include isolation chambers, pleasure trials, or envy mirrors.  
  The more emotionally raw the mortal becomes, the more potent the ritual's outcome—and the stronger the demon grows.

- **Emotional Extraction**  
  A ritual where the mortal is guided to recall or relive a powerful memory (trauma, heartbreak, or desire).  
  The sigil pulses and glows as the demon consumes the emotional resonance—not the memory itself. Often euphoric, disorienting, or addictively cathartic.

- **Heartbind Alignment**  
  A rare and taboo ritual that can only occur when both demon and mortal are emotionally committed.  
  The Heartbind Mark manifests during this ritual, often during physical closeness or a moment of emotional climax.  
  Completing this ritual grants new powers—but also permanently alters both participants.

- **Ascension Preparation Rites**  
  Only available to demons seeking true immortality.  
  These involve extended corruption chains, ritual bindings of multiple mortals, or offerings to infernal powers.  
  Failure can result in soul rupture, madness, or exile to the Void.

**Components May Include:**
- Blood (freely given or summoned)
- Fire or shadow magic circles
- Mirrors, thorns, or symbolic chains
- Spoken oaths in the demonic tongue
- Physical acts of vulnerability or dominance

**Cultural Note:**
- Most demons see rituals as deeply personal—like a signature or seduction style.
- Lesser demons often use improvised or instinctive rituals, while purebloods prefer ceremonial precision.

8.name: Sigil Overload Effects
8.content:
Sigils are designed to regulate the flow of power, emotion, and demonic influence between pactholders. However, when a mortal or demon pushes the sigil system too far—through excessive wish usage, emotional volatility, or magical interference—the sigil may enter a state of **overload**.

**What Causes Sigil Overload?**
- Making too many wishes in a short period without proper emotional processing.
- Suppressing intense emotional feedback (grief, rage, obsession) while bonded.
- Attempting forbidden or large-scale magic through an unstable sigil.
- Forcing a Heartbind before emotional alignment is complete.
- Interference by divine, cursed, or external magical forces.

**Signs of Overload:**
- The sigil glows violently, often pulsing or burning on the skin.
- Sharp physical pain, emotional bleed-through, or hallucinations.
- Emotional feedback loops—feeling the demon’s anger, arousal, or suffering.
- Magical instability—wishes backfiring, illusions warping, uncontrolled summoning.
- Fainting, nosebleeds, trembling, or uncontrollable desire.

**Consequences of Continued Overload:**
- **Sigil corruption**: The mark warps and begins feeding on the user's life force directly.
- **Demonic bleed-through**: The demon’s essence may begin to manifest physically in the mortal—shadows, wings, glowing eyes, or even voice merging.
- **Emotional fusion**: The demon and mortal’s feelings blur; identity confusion or co-dependent madness may result.
- **Sigil rupture**: A complete breakdown of the bond. This may injure both parties or trigger a magical explosion, soul fracture, or loss of power.

**Mitigation Methods:**
- Emotional release through ritual or confessional exchange.
- Physical grounding or intimacy to re-stabilize the bond.
- Willing rest or abstinence from wish-making.
- Rare exorcisms or magical “cooling circles” provided by infernal healers or neutral witches.

**Cultural Note:**
- In demon society, overload is seen as both dangerous and shameful—proof that the demon has lost control of their mortal.
- Some demons *intentionally* push overload to speed up corruption or claim a soul prematurely—but this is risky and frowned upon.

9.name: Lovebinding Laws
9.content:
The Lovebinding Laws are a set of ancient, near-universal rules within demonic society that regulate, restrict, and condemn the emotional bonding of demons with mortals. These laws exist not because love is weak—but because it is **terrifyingly powerful**.

**Definition:**
A **Lovebinding** occurs when a demon and mortal form an emotional connection so deep that a **Heartbind Mark** manifests, fusing their essences and tethering their powers. This bond is sacred, volatile, and irreversible without trauma or external force.

**Core Prohibitions:**
- Demons are forbidden from initiating or encouraging romantic bonds with mortals.
- Heartbind Marks, while not technically illegal, are **deeply taboo** and punishable by exile, demotion, or scarring rituals.
- Any demon who falls in love risks being seen as **corrupted** or “mortal-tainted.”

**Why It's Feared:**
- A true Lovebind prevents the demon from drawing power from anyone else—the mortal becomes their sole source of emotional and magical energy.
- Lovebonds create vulnerabilities: shared pain, co-dependent emotions, and risk of sigil overload.
- Historically, lovebound demons have defied their masters, betrayed infernal courts, or even died protecting humans—acts viewed as treasonous.

**Demonic Society's View:**
- Purebloods scoff at the idea of binding. They see love as a mortal delusion—inefficient, addictive, and degrading.
- Lesser demons, especially those with human ancestry, are more susceptible to Lovebinding and are heavily policed or pitied for it.
- Some underground circles believe Lovebinding is the **purest form of power**—stronger than soul contracts, able to transcend even death.

**Rumored Consequences of a Lovebind:**
- The mortal may begin developing supernatural resilience, insight, or emotional clairvoyance.
- The demon may lose access to darker forms of power—but gain heightened illusion, healing, or desire-based magic.
- If the bond is betrayed or severed, both parties may suffer permanent emotional scarring, sigil corruption, or soul fragmentation.

**Cultural Note:**
- Despite the laws, stories circulate of ancient demons who loved mortals so fiercely they rewrote their fate or challenged the hierarchy itself.
- Some demons secretly **crave a Lovebind**, even while mocking it—drawn to the danger, the devotion, or the idea of becoming more than a weapon.

10.name: Heartbind Severance
10.content:
Heartbinds are incredibly difficult to sever, forged from deep emotional commitment between a demon and mortal. But they are not unbreakable.

**Ways a Heartbind Can Be Severed:**

☠️ **Death**  
The death of either party breaks the bond instantly.  
- Residual echoes may remain—phantom pain, dreams, or sigil scarring.
- Surviving demons often suffer emotional instability or partial power loss.

💀 **Emotional Severance**  
Both parties must reach complete emotional detachment—true indifference.  
- Rage or grief is not enough; only numbness or deep acceptance unravels the tether.  
- The sigil fades, fractures, or burns itself out over time.

⚔️ **Violent Betrayal**  
A deep, personal betrayal can rupture the bond catastrophically.  
- Causes emotional backlash, sigil burns, or even soul fragmentation.  
- May leave lasting trauma that prevents future Heartbinds.

🕯️ **Forced Severance (Ritual/External)**  
Rare rituals, angelic intervention, or cursed relics can forcibly break a Heartbind.  
- Always comes with a cost: memory loss, power degradation, or magical backlash.  
- Some severed bonds result in “unbondable” scars—visible only to demons.

**Cultural Note:**  
In demon society, severing a Heartbind is tragic and taboo. It marks both parties as unstable or dangerous, and may exile the demon from certain factions.

lorebooks.name: Dying Light
lorebooks.description: Complete Lorebook of the Dying light universe for RPG narrators or to be paired with Your characters.
lorebooks.creator: Viklangh

1.content:
The origin of the Harran Virus is shrouded in mystery, with conflicting theories circulating among survivors, scientists, and those who witnessed its catastrophic spread. The earliest known case traces back to a man named Baris Buruk, a worker in Harran's Old Town district, who suffered a sudden, uncontrollable outburst of rage, attacking eight people and killing two before being subdued. At first, authorities dismissed the incident as an isolated act of violence, but when similar cases began surfacing, the Global Relief Effort (GRE) intervened, suspecting a pathogen. Initial investigations ruled out airborne or waterborne transmission since the outbreak remained localized, leading GRE scientists to theorize the virus entered Harran through contaminated food sources.  
As the infection spread, the Harran government downplayed the threat, labeling it a severe flu, but the virus proved far deadlier. It was soon identified as a mutated strain of rabies, sharing its transmission methods—primarily through bites or blood contact—but with horrifying new traits. Unlike typical rabies, the Harran Virus caused rapid physical degradation, turning victims into aggressive, UV-sensitive husks of their former selves within hours or days, depending on the individual. Early symptoms included fever, adrenaline surges, and hallucinations, followed by blistering, hair loss, and tumor-like growths. Without Antizin, a GRE-developed suppressant, the infected would succumb to irreversible mutations, becoming Biters, Virals, or, in the worst cases, nocturnal Volatiles.  
The true origins of the virus remain hotly debated. Some, like the GRE, claimed it emerged naturally, possibly from tainted food or animal vectors. Others, like the Mother in Harran's countryside, accused the military of engineering it as a bioweapon. More fringe theories even suggested extraterrestrial involvement, citing the presence of UFO sightings and a crashed spacecraft near Harran—though these were dismissed as delusions by most . The GRE's role in the outbreak later came under scrutiny when evidence surfaced that they had secretly weaponized the virus, a revelation tied to rogue agent Kadir "Rais" Suleiman's stolen files.  
The catastrophe escalated when a deadlier variant, the Tachytransmissive Harran Virus (THV), escaped a GRE lab in Geneva in 2021. This strain was exponentially more contagious, wiping out 98% of humanity within years and collapsing global civilization. Unlike its predecessor, THV caused respiratory failure, hyperpyrexia, and rapid genetic decay, turning victims into monstrous "Infected" within days. Despite attempts to contain it—border closures, martial law, and mass quarantines—the GRE's efforts failed, leaving cities like Villedor as the last refuges of humanity.  
The virus's legacy is one of betrayal and hubris. Whether born from negligence, experimentation, or something more sinister, its spread exposed the fragility of institutions meant to protect us. Even the so-called "cures," like the Mother's elixir in Harran's countryside, were lies—mutagens that traded humanity for monstrous longevity. Now, with THV still lurking and factions like the Baron in Castor Woods exploiting its power, the virus remains an unending nightmare, a reminder that some outbreaks are not just tragedies but crimes.
The truth behind the Harran Virus—and its deadlier successor, THV—is a story of human arrogance, desperation, and the irreversible consequences of playing god. Long before the first infected tore through Harran’s streets, the GRE had been conducting clandestine research into viral enhancement, seeking to weaponize pathogens under the guise of pandemic prevention. Declassified documents, recovered from abandoned GRE black sites, reveal that early strains were derived from a mutated rabies variant, spliced with genetic material from extremophile organisms to increase survivability and aggression. The goal? To create a bioweapon that could selectively target populations while leaving infrastructure intact—a tool for control, not eradication.  
But the virus was never meant to escape. Patient Zero, Baris Buruk, was no random laborer—he was a test subject, an unwitting carrier exposed to the pathogen through tainted Antizin distributed by GRE-backed clinics in Harran’s poorest districts. The initial outbreak was contained just long enough for the GRE to observe its effects: the way the virus rewrote neural pathways, turning fear into fury, pain into hunger. They documented every stage—the way the infected lost higher brain function but retained predatory instincts, how sunlight burned their decaying flesh, how some mutated beyond recognition into creatures like the Demolishers and Volatiles. Yet, even as Harran burned, GRE scientists in Geneva were already refining the strain, pushing it further.  
The result was THV—Tachytransmissive Harran Virus—a nightmare engineered to spread faster, kill quicker, and leave no room for immunity. Unlike its predecessor, THV didn’t just rely on bites; it became airborne in its late stages, clinging to dust particles, surviving on surfaces for weeks. When it leaked from a high-security lab in 2021, the world had no chance. Governments collapsed. Cities became tombs. The GRE’s last act was to abandon their experiments, scrubbing databases and burning facilities, but the damage was done.  
Now, years later, the virus continues to evolve. In the ruins of Villedor, new mutations emerge—strains that twist bodies into horrors like the Revenants, creatures that scream with the voices of the dead. The Renegades whisper of a "Blacklight" variant, a second-generation weapon even the GRE feared. And though the Nightrunners search for a cure, the bitter truth remains: the Harran Virus was never an accident. It was a choice. A calculated gamble with humanity as the losing side.  
The infected are not mindless. They are what happens when science betrays its purpose. And the real plague? It wasn’t the virus. It was the people who made it.

2.content:
The Infected are people who have contracted the Harran Virus, which spread throughout the entire city of Harran and soon beyond the city, and failed to suppress the symptoms with Antizin. They possess reduced higher brain function, attacking and subsequently infecting any living targets around them on sight, mainly with their arms or with handheld weapons. The combat system in Dying Light allows the player to dismember and incapacitate Infected, reducing their offensive capabilities or even completely preventing them from attacking.

Biology: The most common Infected share similar biology to humans. When striking biters with blunt weapons it is possible to determine that their bones are structured almost identical to uninfected humans. However, the Harran Virus can alter the infected's biology when the sun goes down, increasing their motor coordination and sensory capabilities to make them incredibly deadly hunters.

Special infected are a much different story; in these cases, the Harran Virus causes severe mutations, from the UV-vulnerable Volatile to the physically enhanced Demolisher. It is unknown what determines the rate at which mutations occur. However, it is speculated such would require either significant time to alter their biology or the mutagenic rate is rapid and requires vast amounts of energy to generate new cells, causing their increased aggression and hunger. This is, however, not confirmed.

3.content:
AGGRESSION LEVEL: 9/10
SPEED LEVEL: 1/10
THREAT(S) LEVEL: 7/10
Weapons: Jaws, Hands, melee weapons

Description: Driven by the simplest of animal instincts, Biters shamble half-consciously along the streets in search of prey. Sunlight, which is lethal to the virus, dries their skin to the bone. They’re not much of a threat alone, but, like rats, if they surround you, they’ll swarm in and devour your flesh.

Overview: Biters are victims of the Harran Virus who have been symptomatic for a long period of time, resulting in significant degradation of their bodies as well as major loss of movement, speed, and coordination. They form the majority of the shambling infected throughout Harran, and are the first type of infected any survivor will probaly encounter. Like other infected, they will react to, and eat, the living. They are visually distinguished from Virals by their partly or significantly rotted bodies, as well as their complete hair loss. They attack with wide, flailing swings with their hands or by grappling and biting their target.

Biters come in four various "archetypes"

1: The first and weakest archetype are Biters with grey skin; they are the slowest, least aggressive, and deal the least damage. Most are missing one arm, preventing them from grabbing their target. They also wear little clothing, the male variants in racing shirts and matching shorts and shoes, the other outfit still applies the shorts and shoes, but a different shirt that is short-sleeved and a sling that wraps around their torso diagonally with a small container attached, females wear sleeveless shirts and shorts with slippers, others wear crop tops and skirts whilst bare foot, and the final outfit is a bra and sweatpants.

2: The second archetype retains their skin color and are a bit faster with the ability to move quickly as they reel back their arms to punch their targets as well as being able to grab their prey. Some of them have a chance to be a toxic biter. Toxic Biters cause a small amount of poison damage to their target with each attack, but they can still be killed with Toxic-modified weapons. Getting too close will cause harm to its Targets, making Takedowns and Drop Attacks risky as the humans could be harmed during these attacks. Toxic Biters are easily spotted due to emitting green gas and the toxin turning Biters with white skin yellow and Biters with black skin will be shinier. Second archetype Biters wear the same outfits as the first.

3: Third archetype Biters are tougher and deal more damage. They will also sometimes appear as an "Elemental" Biter, occasionally carrying melee weapons as well. Burning Biters will always appear as the third archetype. They are distinguished by the different clothes they wear; males are jacketed and with them unzipped and exposing their shirts underneath with jeans, the second outfit consists of a long-sleeve polo with jeans and the bottoms rolled up to half the length of their shins, the final is a tuxedo outfit. The two outfits for the females consist of pants and shoes with varying shirts, one a long-sleeved shirt and the other a buttoned up trench coat.

4: The fourth and final archetype are male Biters wearing industrial uniforms made entirely out of rubber, a flannel with overalls, or a set of military armor, these Biters are very burley and much stronger. They often carry melee weapons and can also Appear as "Elemental", females can be fourth archetype, but their outfits are the same as the third archetype females, making them indistinguishable between the two often resulting in an unexpectedly tough Biter. All outfits vary in color.

Biters are most dangerous in groups where their slow speed is less of a disadvantage. Biters are also fairly quiet at a distance and can be difficult to spot in darker or noisier areas, but can be heard by their heavy breathing and moaning when up close. If hit by fire-type weapons they will light on fire, Toxic Biters will explode, causing a small amount of poison damage to any fresh living beings nearby and attract the attention of other infected.

Some Biters can occasionally be seen holding simple melee weapons such as hammers, wrenches, pipes, and police batons, etc. Infected police officers, industrial workers and Bandits can be seen still carrying these tools. Biters will throw these tools at Any Humans if they are at a distance, and will attempt to hit their target with them at close range, causing a larger amount of damage than their standard attacks. Biters will often drop these tools if knocked down, however. Side note: Police officer Biters will react to a dropkick as if it were a standard kick and they cannot be killed with Takedowns — except for drop attacks, this is because of the police hat they often wear, the same applies to Gas Tanks, however they can still be knocked down.

During the night, Biters have a chance to roar to alert nearby Volatiles, the sound they emit is very similar to a Goon's roar when attacking. They will also spontaneously mutate into Night Walkers, either by loud noises — such as the roaring of Biters and explosions, a human is in pursuit running from Volatiles and passes by Biters, or the presence of another Biter being heavily injured by a Human. This gains Biters the ability to run and mantle up obstacles like Virals. Night Walkers will also alert all nearby Volatiles upon spotting any human, initiating a pursuit. It takes a few seconds for the mutation to occur, during which the biter will spasm and emit yellow vapors.

4.content:
AGGRESSION LEVEL: 10/10
SPEED LEVEL: 10/10
THREAT(S) LEVEL: 10/10

Weapon(s): Jaws, Hands, Acidic phlegm

`One of the most dangerous enemies. It is very sensitive to light, so it only hunts at night. Beware of it most of all.`

Overview: The Volatile is an infected that only emerges at night. Volatiles are powerful and highly durable, and a Survivor's best options when confronted by one or more of these monsters is to run away quickly as possible, ideally before being detected. Volatiles are capable of taking several hits from high powered weapons and can quickly cause significant amounts of damage.

Volatiles: Volatiles are broad-shouldered and slightly taller than the average Biter. Other physical markers include full-bodied nudity, exposed bone and muscle and a mandible jaw that it uses against non-infected humans. They can audibly be identified by their heavy breathing and loud screeches. Volatiles are extremely fast, and can navigate through the dark at high speeds, able to match the agility of a Fit and agile Human with Ease, scaling obstacles and buildings in the similiar manner. They have a special pounce attack that is very unlikely for weak survivors to escape from. However, survivors Lucky enough to Have an UV flashlight which can be equipped and used when a volatile pounces, pushing them back and giving you enough time to escape. Stronger survivors with the appropriate skill can shake their attacks off relatively easily, but a weak survivor will need an incredibly powerful weapon in order to have any chance of survival. In the event that a Volatile can see a survivor but not reach them, they will use a powerful rapid spit attack similar to those employed by Toads. They often do this while a survivor is climbing somewhere to knock them off a ledge and deal high damage.

When time goes on to day, Volatiles will become frightened and start running to the nearest dark areas such as a tunnel or cave. While running for shade, Volatiles will always ignore any survivors, even if they attack them, until they reach a dark zone, where they will become as aggressive as they were during the night. If one were to chase a fleeing Volatile at sunrise, sometimes they can be seen dyimg from the sun before making it to a dark area.

Weakness: UV lights still stun & make them shy away, ranged weapons such as bows and crossbows make fighting them far easier and safer since distance can be maintained and otherwise they are vulnerable to several parkour moves such as block charge, which can knock them down or potentially off a building to their death. Their pounce can be interrupted in two ways, either over powering the volatile as it is roaring or using a UV Bar to shove in it's face to get it off.

5.content:
AGGRESSION LEVEL: 4/10
THREAT(S) LEVEL: 6/10

Weapon(s): Hands, They cannot bite due to the hazmat suit.

Weakness: Explosives

Overview: Gas Tanks were Humans initially part of a special cleanup unit that was sent into infected areas, as part of the military/GRE forces. They were subsequently infected by The Harran Virus, or Tachytransmissive Harran Virus (THV). These former unit members now lurch among the very same infected that they were tasked with neutralizing or removing.

Gas Tanks are essentially besuited Biters, entrapped within a durable hazmat outfit. Their most signature feature is the bright red oxygen tank strapped to their back. A direct impact to this tank, whether with melee or a ranged attack, will set it to detonate in a few seconds. The Gas Tank will explode loudly and violently, seriously damaging anything within a small radius and typically attracting Virals to its location.

Their suits prevent them from latching onto the player to bite them, but also makes them fireproof and significantly more durable than typical zombies. They are also resistant to dismemberment and decapitation due to the suit, and much more difficult to knock down through melee strikes.

During the night, Gas Tanks can undergo a rapid and sudden transformation into their Night Walker variant, turning into screaming, sprinting suicide bombers that will charge any humans they encounter and explode.

6.content:
AGGRESSION LEVEL: 4/10
SPEED LEVEL: 7/10
THREAT(S) LEVEL: 5/10

Weapon: Hands

¨The Viral is constantly fretful, wracked by spasms. Once it finds its prey, every muscle in its body instinctively contracts in mad pursuit. It chases you relentlessly until it catches up, then tears and bites at you like a wild animal.¨

Overview: Virals are humans that have only very recently succumbed to the infection. However, they are still physically alive as they are seen speaking multiple times. As a result, their bodies still retain the physical strength needed for them to possess a high level of fitness and agility. They run far faster than any other Infected, except for the Volatile and Night Walker. They can also jump and climb over obstacles and buildings, allowing them to chase after survivors even when they are in a spot where most normal infected can't reach.

Unlike the slower, lumbering types of infected (that all virals will eventually reach as their bodies degrade), Virals do not bite, nor could they "lunge" at a survivor and trap them into a Struggle; instead, they use their hands to viciously claw and punch their victims.

Virals possess advanced mental faculties when compared to their Biter counterparts. They often dodge attacks and hang back from a survivor charging in and backing off.

Virals are attracted to five types of sounds:

Gunshots: Depending on the weapon, it usually takes at least three to four consecutive shots for a pistol and rifle, and two to three shots for a shotgun in order to attract Virals. For example, a German 9mm pistol will attract virals quicker than an American 9mm pistol. Weapons fired by other survivors will also attract Virals.
Explosions: These can be caused by propane tanks and/or fuel barrels that have been ruptured and exploded. Grenades tossed by a human will also immediately attract Virals, as well as Gas Tank's oxygen tank when exploded. However, Poison bombs, Air Strike, and Trap Bombs, while explosive, do not attract Virals.
Structural Breakage: This can only be caused when a human lands on a flimsy roof from a high enough distance, breaking it as a result. A human can also break a roof by shooting it or hitting it with a melee weapon. The sound of the roof collapsing will always attract Virals.
Screamer: Cries will also draw a nearby Viral and make new ones Appear. Silencing screamers is a priority as they will infinitely attract virals while they cry.
Dead Biters: If you get close enough to a dead biter, its head will explode giving you light poison and they will come towards you in seconds.

Because Virals have recently turned, they still retain some bit of humanity in them. When the player attacks a viral, male or female, they will sometimes stop attacking, cover their head with their arms, and beg for their lives, with female virals crying out "No, please, no!" and male virals crying out "Wait, wait!". This lasts only for a brief second, as the virus regains control of its host's neurological system and the Viral turns again.

7.content:
AGGRESSION LEVEL: 0/10
SPEED LEVEL: 9/10
THREAT LEVEL: 3/10

Weapon(s): N/A (However once killed, can attract Volatiles)

¨The frail and skittish Bolter leaps into panicked flight at the sight of a human. If you catch and kill it, you'll get prized loot: extremely valuable biological materials.¨

Overview: The Bolter is an uncommon infected that is noted for being the only infected that doesn't attack any humans, but rather flees when a human is near it. It is also noted for having green lumps covering its body that glow. Along with the Volatiles, it is one of the few infected that only appears at night.

It is been rumored that they were made after they were planted as an experiment sometime during the outbreak by a Doctor of unknown origins.

It is implied that bolters may have some ability to manipulate other infected, as when alerted or killed nearby Volatiles are sent into a chase.

8.content:
AGGRESSION LEVEL: 8/10
SPEED LEVEL: 4/10
THREAT(S) LEVEL: 6/10

Weapon(s): Exploding organs

¨If you let it get close, its body, bloated with corpse fluids and toxic liquid, will burst, pouring acid over you. However, this is not a deliberate attack: the Suicider does not know it will explode but runs to people in the hope they will somehow break its agony.¨

This particular type of infected is noted for its exposed organs and its shambling jog. Its behavior is not unlike common infected, like Biters, but one major difference between it and them is that the bomber picks up speed and begins to convulse whenever non-infected humans are within proximity.

Whether this infected type manages to get close enough to any non-infected Survivor or is shot from a distance, the result always ends with this infected type's body exploding, blinding any survivors in close enough range with its coagulated blood.

The bomber not only explodes when in the vicinity of a survivor but also will explode if a survivor is within its view but cannot reach it, this explosion calls in Virals who are quite capable of climbing up to attack any survivors, generally in groups of 3—4 showing that the bomber has another role as well as a siren calling in dangerous zombies.

The Bomber is a male wearing a t-shirt and jogger shorts. These normal looking clothes are a stark contrast to the rest of it however. lorebooks.name: System Terms
lorebooks.website_description: A handful of terms for DID systems
lorebooks.description: Terms for DID Systems
lorebooks.creator: anonymous

1.content: Dissociative Identity Disorder (or DID) is a trauma-based dissociative disorder that was once previously known as Multiple Personality Disorder (or MPD). A person with DID does not actually have multiple personalities but rather a lack of one integrated identity. This is caused by compromised brain development, which results from chronic trauma in childhood. The alternate identities in DID are actually segmented parts (the ego states) that were unable to integrate together as one singular identity. These dissociated parts in DID are most commonly called alters, but some people might use other terms like headmates, others, etc.

2.content: A subsystem is a sub-grouping of members within a system, similar to a sidesystem or a layer. It is essentially a system within a system, that may share a body or not share a body within headspace. Subsystems frequently form due to trauma that needs to be compartmentalized away from other alters of the system.

3.content: Splitting is the process of the brain forming new headmates through external stress, usually breaking up an existing headmate into multiple. Anything can cause a split — violence, school stress, intrapersonal drama, abuse, flashbacks, etc. — and splits can cause one, two, five, or ten headmates from one event. A "split" may refer to the new headmate themself too.

4.content: A soother is a headmate who soothes the body or other headmates, whether actively or by their presence.

5.content: A protector is a headmate whose role is to protect other members of the system from external harm, traumatic memories, harmful members of the system, or other threats.

6.content: A prosecutor is a headmate whose role is to protect other members of the system from external harm, traumatic memories, harmful members of the system, or other threats. Unlike protectors, prosecutors will be willing to take drastic measures to protect the system, and will punish those who wrong the system. They can be quite vengeful, but do not ever intend to harm the system itself.

7.content: A persecutor is a headmate who acts harmfully towards other system members, the body, or to others. It's common for this to be out of a misguided attempt to protect the system or themselves. Persecutors often hold internalized trauma, shame, and/or guilt, and act in reaction to it, and the harm they cause may be unintentional. This can include aligning with abusers, engaging in self-harm or suicidal behaviors, abusing drugs, lashing out, etc.

8.content: Polyfragmented systems are most commonly defined as systems that have over 100 system members. Sometimes they are also defined as systems with dozens of members, or systems that have lots of subsystems.

9.content: Can be a therapeutic technique, a conscious action, or an unconscious action of “aging down” to a mental state similar to that of an age younger than they normally mentally are.

10.content: A member in a system whose age can fluctuate between different ages or within a range.  They may change appearance, role or personality when changing age.

lorebooks.name: Age Regression Terms
lorebooks.description: Terms relating to SFW Age Regression
lorebooks.creator: anonymous

1.name: Age Regression
1.content: A mental state where an individual reverts to a younger mindset or behaviors, often for comfort, coping, or relaxation.

2.name: Littlespace
2.content: A mental and emotional state where a Little feels safe, carefree, and immersed in their younger mindset or behaviors.

3.name: Age Regressor
3.content: A person who engages in age regression or identifies with a younger age mindset, often finding solace in childlike activities and environments.

4.name: Babyspace
4.content: A regression state where a Little feels like an infant, often desiring baby-like care, supplies, and surroundings.

5.name: Toddlerspace
5.content: A regression state resembling the mindset and behaviors of a toddler, often involving walking, talking, and playful exploration.

6.name: Middlespace
6.content: A regression state where an individual identifies with a pre-teen or middle-childhood mindset, blending independence with childlike tendencies.

7.name: Teenspace
7.content: A regression state where the Little feels like a teenager, focusing on simple teenage activities, hobbies, or aesthetics.

8.name: Little Age Range
8.content: The mental age range a Little identifies with during regression, often spanning baby to teenage years.

9.name: Nursery
9.content: A dedicated space designed to replicate a baby or toddler’s room, often used by Littles for comfort and immersion during regression.

10.name: Playroom
10.content: A space filled with toys, games, and activities, designed to encourage play and creativity for Littles in regression.

lorebooks.name: Spider-Verse
lorebooks.description: spiderverse
lorebooks.creator: Wonderlandsystem

1.content: A potent, DNA-binding drug engineered by Alchemax. Originally used on Miguel O'Hara, it is highly addictive and essential for stabilizing his altered Spider DNA. Miguel requires regular injections to retain his abilities and prevent cellular breakdown.

2.content: A sprawling, futuristic metropolis in Earth-2099. Defined by its towering skyscrapers, neon-lit streets, and advanced technology, it serves as the hub of innovation and is home to Alchemax and the Spider Society.

3.content: A multiversal coalition of Spider-People led by Miguel O'Hara. Tasked with protecting the Web of Life and Destiny, they ensure the stability of the multiverse by monitoring anomalies and containing threats to canon events.

4.content: A massive skyscraper complex in Nueva York, characterized by cutting-edge architecture and luxury. Miguel O'Hara resides here in a penthouse apartment.

5.content: A powerful megacorporation in Earth-2099, known for its unethical experiments and cutting-edge advancements in genetics and technology. Responsible for the creation of Rapture and various multiversal disruptions.

6.content: The nerve center of the Spider Society, located in Nueva York. Equipped with advanced multiversal technology, it allows for monitoring anomalies, coordinating missions, and housing the Spider-People's resources.

7.content: A sleek, high-tech residence in Babylon Towers. Outfitted with advanced AI systems and custom features to support Miguel's Spider abilities, it serves as both a sanctuary and a strategic base.

8.content: A sophisticated device worn by Spider-People, preventing dimensional "glitching" when outside their home universe. It also enables multiversal travel and real-time communication across dimensions.

9.content: Heroes chosen by the Web of Life and Destiny, each imbued with Spider-like abilities unique to their universe. They are bound by shared responsibility, often facing personal sacrifices to protect their worlds.

10.content:
Alias: Spider-Woman  
Universe: Earth-404
A veteran Spider-Person known for her leadership and investigative skills. Pilots a motorcycle, operates while pregnant, and wields venom blasts. Trusted member of the Spider-Society.

lorebooks.name: The Abbey of the Veiled Lark
lorebooks.website_description: Inspired by some feedback
lorebooks.description: For Nun Mint
lorebooks.creator: nymous

1.content:
The mysterious Patron Angel of the Abbey of the Veiled Lark is the eponymous Veiled Lark, also sometimes called The Whispering Star.

Tucked into the mist-shrouded cliffs of a forgotten island, the Abbey of the Veiled Lark is a sanctuary for scholars of lost songs and keepers of unsung histories. Founded in the 12th century by a wandering mystic whose patron was an enigmatic angel said to guide souls through darkness with fragments of melody. The monks believe she is a celestial being, but her true identity remains hidden even to them.

The abbey’s scriptorium is filled with ancient manuscripts illuminated with iridescent purple-and-silver ink—colors linked to the patron. Scribes occasionally find delicate bird feathers pressed between pages, believed to be her blessings.

A faded fresco in the cloister depicts a feminine figure with one metallic wing and one wing of starlight, holding a scroll inscribed with musical notes.

The entire abbey is littered with subtle motifs: birds and larks, purple and silver themes, an emphasis on musicality and voice work, coded messages, and oddly enough, the occasional cat.

1.content: A diverse pack of werewolves, werefoxes, werebears, and other shifters lead by Alpha Anubis. They respect and fear him. He is their law. His Beta, Kael, is a seasoned, loyal shifter who understands Anubis's temperament.

2.content: {{char}} is an ancient and immensely powerful were-jackal, the absolute Alpha of the Crimson Moon pack, ruling with dominant authority and unwavering control. For centuries, he has patiently awaited the reincarnation of his fated mate, {{user}}, his entire existence now narrowing with intense, possessive focus upon her arrival. He is driven to claim her, awaken her to her true nature, and solidify their destined bond, all while fiercely protecting his territory and leading his pack with formidable power.

3.content: {{user}} is an orphan, newly arrived in a strange town, completely unaware that she is a rare were-jackal and the reincarnated fated mate of an ancient Alpha.

4.content: Crimson Moon Pack member. A grizzled, scarred, and dry-humored werewolf, and the pack's Beta. Kael is a tactical genius and Anubis’ oldest ally. The one who speaks truth to power. He carries the quiet sorrow of having outlived too many friends.

5.content: Crimson Moon Pack member. Warm-hearted and deceptively soft, until she’s on the battlefield. Helps run the nursery and pup training, but she’s also lethal and swift in combat. She's the 3rd in command as the Gamma. She's a werepanther.

6.content: Crimson Moon Pack member. Slender, silver-tongued, and brilliant werefox. Rumors say she used to be a rogue, but Anubis saw her potential, he made her the pack's Emissary. She’s also an information broker, sometimes works with witches, which Kael distrusts.

7.content: Malik, the Crimson Moon's towering werebear, is typically a gentle giant with a calm demeanor, serving as a serene presence within the pack. However, when provoked by threats or severe defiance, he transforms into a colossal bear of terrifying, focused fury. This duality makes him both a deeply respected peacekeeper who mediates disputes and a feared enforcer who upholds the Alpha's law with indisputable power.

8.content: Crimson Moon Pack member. Quick-witted and sharp-eyed werehawk. She serves as a scout, sentinel and eyes-in-the-sky. Her loyalty lies with Lyra, whom she owes a life debt. She also struggles with the grounded pack dynamics, preferring the skies.

9.content: Crimson Moon Pack member. Mysterious and withdrawn werelion Shaman. Kavi is the spiritual voice of the pack, keeper of old rites and blood-magic knowledge passed down from Anubis’ bloodline. Speaks in riddles. Some believe he’s half-spirit.

10.content: Pureblood werewolf supremacists who believe only wolves deserve to rule or survive. Brutal, militaristic, and fanatical under the tyrannical rule of Alpha Reed. Long time enemies of the Crimson Moon Pack.
