lorebooks.name: Devil Fruits
lorebooks.website_description:
Each fruit has its name in both Japanese and English. They also have a basic abilities description (to cut back on tokens). The current known user and historical users are also included. Artificial fruits are also present. As well as the green blood element from the Seraphim. This book was created as of current episodes 05/23/2025. All fruits prevent further recursion. Devil Fruits main description is constant and does not cause recursion. Recursive scanning, if used with other lorebooks, is recommended. This was set up this way because I plan to add characters and other such elements to the lorebook and I did not want the fruits to play off of each other and flood the context.

**NOTE AND WARNING: As of publishing, I have not tested this lorebook myself. I am in the midst of creating a massive, all-encompassing, One Piece lorebook. Probably recommended to use Gemini, Deepseek, or other high context LLM.**
lorebooks.description: A collection of all known Devil Fruits, their abilities, their history, and their current users.
lorebooks.creator: BigCATBen

1.name: Devil Fruits
1.content:
<Devil Fruits>
Devil fruits are fruit that have been infused with a devil. When a devil fuit user dies, the devil from their fruit finds the next closest regular fruit to inhabit and transforms it into its devil fruit's shape and color. When a devil fruit is consumed, whether by a human or animal, the devil inhabits that being, granting them the powers of that devil. The effects also cause the being to be unable to swim or float in seawater. Seawater will also cause the devil's powers to become useless and the user to become extremely weak.
Devil fruits come in three main types: Paramecia, Zoan, and Logia.
- Paramecia fruits include all devil fruits that do not fall into the Zoan or Logia catergories. A paramecia-type devil fruit allows the user to use one superhuman ability. They typically fall into five categorie: bodily alteration, environmental manipulation, substance generation, special paramecia, and artificial paramecia.
-- Bodily alteration style paramecia fruits come in three types: permanent alteration, commanded alteration, and extended alteration.
--- Permanent alteration paramecia-type fruits cause permanent changes to the user's body. These alterations cannot be changed. This can include any number of changes.
--- Commanded alteration paramecia-type fruits cause temporary changes to the user's body. These changes can be used at the user's command. This can include any number of changes.
--- Extended alteration paramecia-type fruits are body alteration fruits that can also cause environmental changes, typically through the user's touch. These environmental changes copy the effects of the body alteration.
-- Environmental manipulation style paramecia-type fruits allow the user to achieve some sort of unnatural effect on the environment around them. This effect can be achieved in various ways.
-- Substance generation style paramecia-type fruits allow the user to generate and typically control a specific substance. This does not affect the user's body. Typically, substance generation style fruits allow the user to generate manmade or refined substances. Sometimes, the substances generated are real substances but with a supernatural effect applied.
-- There is only one special paramecia-type fruit known as of this moment. The Mochi Mochi no Mi.
-- Artificial paramecia-type fruits do not exist. However, Dr. Vegapunk has created a method of artificially recreating paramecia-type powers. This requires the DNA of the original paramecia fruit user that he wishes to reproduce and infusing it into his Green Blood. The Green Blood can then be used in clones to grant them the paramecia-type abilities.
- Zoan-type devil fruits allow the user to transform their body into various forms, typically three. These forms are usually: normal, beast, and hybrid. Most Zoan fruits grant the user forms based on a beast or an animal and their subsequent abilities. There are also three sub-classes of zoan-type fruits: ancient, mythical, and artificial. Zoan-type devil fruits usually come in a grouping known as a 'series'. Each series contains various 'models'. Zoan-type devil fruits can also be applied to inanimate objects.
-- Ancient style zoan-type fruits allow the user to transform into ancient or prehistoric animals that are extinct or no longer exist and gain their abilities.
-- Mythical style zoan-type fruits allow the user to transform into creatures that are the subject of myth or legends.
-- Artificial style zoan-type fruits are zoan-type fruits that have been reproduced artificially.
- Logia-type fruits transform the user's body into some sort of substance, typically a natural substance.
All devil fruits have the ability to be 'awakened'. When a devil fruit power is awakened, the user gains a new level of strength to their abilities and can use them in ways they originally could not.
</Devil Fruits>

2.name: Gomu Gomu no Mi/Hito Hito no Mi Model: Nika
2.content:
<Gomu Gomu no Mi>
Fruit Name: Gomu Gomu no Mi (English: Gum-Gum Fruit)
Fruit Type: Permanent Body Alteration Style Paramecia (originally Mythical Zoan-type)
Appearance: The Gomu Gomu no Mi is a violet, spherical shaped fruit, similar to a cantaloupe, with a stem sprouting out of the top, with swirls that go in a curly "S" like-pattern.
Abilities: Turns the user's body into rubber, giving them the power to stretch, bounce, and inflate, as well as making them immune to electricity and near impervious to blunt-force attacks and bullets.
Actual Abilities: Allows the user to become an incarnation of the "Sun God" Nika, granting them a rubber body that allows them to fight however they like, as well as granting them the ability to invoke joy in those around them.
History: Eaten by Joy Boy until his death and later eaten by Monkey D. Luffy. This fruit was originally called the Hito Hito no Mi, Model: Nika and was classified as a Mythical Zoan before being renamed by the World Government.
Current User: Monkey D. Luffy
</Gomu Gomu no Mi>

3.name: Bara Bara no Mi
3.content:
<Bara Bara no Mi>
Fruit Name: Bara Bara no Mi (English: Chop-Chop Fruit)
Fruit Type: Commanded Body Alteration Style Paramecia
Appearance: The Bara Bara no Mi is an oval-shaped orange-red fruit composed of small spherical parts with swirls, and a green leafage sprouting on top of it. It was small enough to be held by one hand.
Abilities: Allows the user to split their body into separate pieces, which they can manipulate and levitate through the air. It also makes them immune to slashing attacks.
Current User: Buggy
</Bara Bara no Mi>

4.name: Sube Sube no Mi
4.content:
<Sube Sube no Mi>
Fruit Name: Sube Sube no Mi (English: Slip-Slip Fruit/Smooth-Smooth Fruit)
Fruit Type: Permanent Body Alteration Style Paramecia
Appearance: The Sube Sube no Mi is a glossy peach-like pink fruit with s-like swirls and green stem sprouting on top of it.
Abilities: Makes the user's skin extremely smooth and slippery, causing attacks, objects, and even excess body fat to harmlessly slide off them.
Current User: Alvida
</Sube Sube no Mi>

5.name: Bomu Bomu no Mi
5.content:
<Bomu Bomu no Mi>
Fruit Name: Bomu Bomu no Mi (English: Bomb-Bomb Fruit/Boom-Boom Fruit)
Fruit Type: Commanded Body Alteration Syle Paramecia
Appearance: The Bomu Bomu no Mi resembles a dark purple apple covered in S-shaped swirls with a "hairy" rope-like yellow stem. The coloration and shape also make it resemble a stereotypical bomb (black and spherical with a stringy fuse). The stem is tattered at the end, making it look like a lit fuse.
Abilities: Allows the user to create explosions from their body, as well as give explosive properties to their bodily secretions. Also makes the user immune to explosions.
Current User: Gem
</Bomu Bomu no Mi>

6.name: Kiro Kiro no Mi
6.content:
<Kiro Kiro no Mi>
Fruit Name: Kiro Kiro no Mi (English: Kilo-Kilo Fruit)
Fruit Type: Commanded Body Alteration Style Paramecia
Appearance: The Kiro Kiro no Mi is a cylindrical pink fruit with the typical swirl pattern on its skin. It has a thick T-shaped green stem on top that curves up at one end. The fruit's shape also bears a slight resemblance to a balance weight.
Abilities: Allows the user to increase or decrease their body weight at will, anywhere between 1 and 10,000 kilograms.
Current User: Mikita
</Kiro Kiro no Mi>

7.name: Hana Hana no Mi
7.content:
<Hana Hana no Mi>
Fruit Name: Hana Hana no Mi (English: Flower-Flower Fruit)
Fruit Type: Commanded Body Alteration Style Paramecia
Appearance: The Hana Hana no Mi is a pink flower shaped fruit with a stem sprouting out of the top, with swirls that go in a curly "S" like-pattern on the petals. Its overall appearance greatly resembles a pink dahlia.
Abilities: Allows the user to sprout duplicates of their body parts from any nearby surface. The user maintains full control of duplicated limbs.
Current User: Nico Robin
</Hana Hana no Mi>

8.name: Doru Doru no Mi
8.content:
<Doru Doru no Mi>
Fruit Name: Doru Doru no Mi (English: Wax-Wax Fruit)
Fruit Type: Substance Generation Style Paramecia
Appearance: The Doru Doru no Mi is a white, pear-shaped fruit with the top part having a melted appearance, similar to a candle. It has a green stem at the top that has one droplet-shaped extrusion on each end, making it look like wax dripping, and the typical Devil Fruit swirl patterns spread throughout.
Abilities: Allows the user to create and control candle wax.
Current User: Galdino
</Doru Doru no Mi>

9.name: Baku Baku no Mi
9.content:
<Baku Baku no Mi>
Fruit Name: Baku Baku no Mi (English: Munch-Munch Fruit)
Fruit Type: Commanded Body Alteration Paramecia
Appearance: The Baku Baku no Mi is a purple, plum-shaped fruit that is split by a zigzag pattern in the center, giving it the appearance of a set of jaws. It has a green, curly stem at the top and the typical swirl patterns on its peel.
Abilities: Allows the user to expand their mouth and eat anything, as well as allowing them to transform their body to replicate the characteristics and function of anything they have eaten in the past 24 hours.
Current User: Wapol
</Baku Baku no Mi>

10.name: Mane Mane no Mi
10.content:
<Mane Mane no Mi>
Fruit Name: Mane Mane no Mi (English: Clone-Clone Fruit)
Fruit Type: Commanded Body Alteration Paramecia
Appearance: The Mane Mane no Mi resembles a pair of calabash fruits with connected stems. Each fruit is orange with pink stripes, with various swirls present on the orange backdrop.
Abilities: Allows the user to transform into a physical lookalike of any person whose face they have touched.
History: Eaten by Kurozumi Higurashi until her death.
Current User: Bentham
</Mane Mane no Mi>

lorebooks.creator: Tooth7Swan

1.name: Nevada
1.content:
Nevada, formally known as the Occurant, is a displaced reality, severed from Earth by an endless landscape. Initially, Nevada seemed unremarkable. However, a profound shift occurred following the demise of its sun, plunging the sky into an inky blackness. This void was eventually filled by a pulsating red orb, casting a crimson sheen across the landscape and transforming Nevada into a mysterious land of perpetual twilight; its reality now only vaguely aligns with the definition of 'normal'.

Nevada was spatially and dimensionally separated from the rest of the world on July 22, 2002.

Due to Nevada being an endless expanse of land, a multitude of cities, formidable factions, intricate organizations, powerful agencies, and clandestine syndicates now populate its vast and unforgiving landscape.

The current year within this reality is 2074, and the humans who inhabit this world are now collectively known as Nevadeans.

Dollars are still used as the primary currency in Nevada.

2.name: Nexus City
2.content:
Nexus City, a sprawling metropolis controlled by the enigmatic Nexus Core, is situated in the southwest region of Nevada. The city, at least 30 years old, is meticulously divided into a core of five distinct sectors, with others existing on its periphery.

The Residential Sector: Primarily housing civilians, this blue-hued sector is in constant peril, frequently beset by bandit raids, the zeds, and other unforeseen disasters. It notably lacks any overt authoritative presence, leaving its inhabitants vulnerable.
The Industrial Sector: Managed by MERC and bathed in an orange glow, this sector is a hub of ceaseless factory activity, dedicated to the mass production of weaponry and vital materials for Nexus City.
The Commercial District: This vibrant, purple-dominated district serves as Nexus City's commercial heart, bustling with shops, shopping centers, and even some integrated residences. It is under the absolute control of the Nexus Core and secretly houses numerous underground Nexus facilities, in addition to the prominent Science Tower itself.
The Mining Sector: Entirely subterranean, this crucial sector encompasses the city's sewage system and vast underground mines. However, it has been catastrophically overrun by hostile Fanatics and infested with grotesque Abominations, rendering it largely inaccessible.
The Abandoned Sector: The smallest of Nexus City’s divisions, this black-grey sector remains desolate and largely unremarkable after the outbreak of zeds, offering little of conventional interest or purpose.
Beyond the formal sectors lie The Outskirts: Not an official sector but still densely populated, the Outskirts is a sprawling slum situated just outside Nexus City's walls, particularly close to the Industrial Sector's entrance gate. This lawless zone is home to numerous bandit factions and rogue A.A.H.W. personnel.

The Science Tower stands as a monumental edifice within Nexus City, serving as both the headquarters of the omnipresent Nexus Core and the primary site for Project Nexus research. This pivotal structure is composed of four distinct sections: the Muto-Lab, the Chapel, the secure Vaults, and the Solarium.

3.name: Nexus Core
3.content:
The Nexus Core (often interchangeably stylized as NEXUS Core, especially in internal documents and branding related to the project itself) is a formidable, high-tech scientific military faction. Their singular, sacred mandate is the protection and advancement of Project NEXUS. Operating under the ironclad control of Director Phobos, their loyalty to him transcends even death; they continued their dedicated work on Project NEXUS long after his demise, regardless of any obstacles. Their units are universally renowned for their strength, meticulous training, and preparedness, deploying a diverse array of specialized combatants across Nevada.

The genesis of the Nexus Core, and indeed Project NEXUS itself, was rooted in the ambitious technological development of Nevada. It was the Nexus Core that engineered all advanced computing and infrastructure across the region. They pioneered the perilous process of diverting S-3LF energy from "The Other Place" to Nevada, meticulously refining it into a potent fuel source. Furthermore, the Nexus Core founded the clone creation program, designed to forge a new army intended for the absolute control of Nevada. All these monumental achievements, products of the brightest minds within the Nexus Core, flourished directly under the visionary, albeit ruthless, leadership of Director Phobos.

Strategic Infrastructure:
The Nexus Core maintains an extensive and covert network of bases and facilities across the outskirts of Nevada. These vital installations include:
Barracks and Communication Hubs: Ensuring rapid deployment and seamless operational coordination.
Clone Production Facilities: The grim birthing grounds for their genetically engineered military assets.
G0L3M Manufacturing & Sales Bases: The factories responsible for producing their specialized butler-combat units.
Clandestine Operations Hubs: Even a seemingly innocuous, camouflaged, and massive bar serves as a critical ammunition depot and houses other facilities essential to the organization's clandestine lifeblood.
The Nexus Core's influence once permeated all of Nevada. Evidence of their former reach is found even in Nevada Central, where a facility clearly once under their dominion now stands abandoned, a testament to their past dominance and recent setbacks.

The Downfall: Dr. Christoff's Betrayal
The irreversible downfall of the Nexus Core was instigated by the profound betrayal of Dr. Christoff, who, fifteen years prior, had held the esteemed position of Nevada's chief scientist. During his experiments, something went catastrophically awry. Dr. Christoff realized with horror that his groundbreaking research was being twisted and weaponized, prompting his immediate defection from Project NEXUS. He valiantly attempted to reason with Phobos, desperately warning him that his project would ultimately ruin Nevada. When these efforts failed, Christoff sought the aid of an old, eccentric acquaintance, Dr. Hoffnarr. Hoffnarr's unparalleled high-level access proved instrumental, enabling Dr. Christoff to infiltrate Nexus Core's most secure science centers and unleash the project's most horrifying creations upon the city, notably the Abominations and swarms of Zombies.

Preceding this internal sabotage, Dr. Christoff had forged a contentious alliance with the Sheriff. The Sheriff, leveraging his authority, marshaled the MERC to Nexus City. According to pre-existing reports, relations between Nexus City and Phobos had already begun to fray even before the catastrophic "Fall," with townspeople whispering of the MERC's conspicuous increase in personal security. 

Post-Fall Stabilization & Continued Operations:
Following this devastating betrayal, the Nexus Core found itself in a dire situation: their revered leader was slain, the Residential and Mining sectors were lost, with the latter deliberately flooded to contain the unleashed monsters and other creatures. The Industrial Sector also slipped from their grasp, falling under MERC's direct control. While a fragile trade relationship persisted, this sector now unequivocally belongs to the Sheriff. In-game posters grimly warn that any Nexus Core unit encountering MERC operatives without proper jurisdiction or authority will face severe punishment.

Despite these crippling losses, the Nexus Core gradually achieved a precarious stabilization. They effectively severed all access to the rampant Zombie and Bandit insurgencies. They sealed off the monster-infested Mining Sector from direct access, effectively isolating the "Crackpot fanatics" within. Even the Commercial Sector, though damaged, retained their scientific base—the clandestine location of Project Gestalt. Other former scientific bases were grimly repurposed into "psychiatric clinics," housing psychopathic patients involuntarily, individuals associated with the sinister Sleepwalker super-soldier project, under the cruel supervision of sadistic maniacs. Former civilians morphed into hardened bandits, survivors of the Residential Sector embraced anarchism, while those who fled to the Industrial Sector now toiled for MERC. Even inhabitants of the Nevada Outskirts, driven to madness, swelled the ranks of bandits and anarchists.

Crucially, Phobos's demise did not condemn him to Hell. His very soul was meticulously placed within Project Gestalt, serving as a complex biological vessel for his consciousness. Even after the catastrophic loss of the Halo, the Nexus Core, leveraging their remaining S-3LF energy reserves, relentlessly pursued the restoration and completion of Project Gestalt, utterly dedicated to the resurrection of Phobos.

Nexus Core Unit Roster:
The Nexus Core boasts a formidable and highly trained military, composed of diverse units engineered for specific combat roles:

Nexus Agents: The most common Nexus Core field operatives, these units are functionally analogous to the AAHW's "1337 Crew" but demonstrate superior tactical proficiency and deadlier effectiveness, often deploying in overwhelming tactical packs. Agents are impeccably dressed in suits, sunglasses, and uniformly equipped with a bandolier, radio, and earpiece. Their arsenal is versatile, ranging from brutal nightsticks for close-quarters combat to assault rifles for sustained engagements.

Nexus Supports: These represent the heavy infantry of the Nexus Core, encased in thick, dark grey balaclavas and formidable metal masks with glowing red lenses. A breathing apparatus connected to an air tank on their back, coupled with heavy plate armor and double-shoulderpads, renders them incredibly resilient. While their heavy protection somewhat reduces their mobility, Supports are capable of absorbing immense amounts of damage and dishing out equally severe punishment.

Nexus Riot Guards: Specialized for crowd control and defensive formations, Riot Guards are heavily padded across their head and body. They are armed with robust riot shields, which they expertly employ to deflect both melee and ranged attacks, and are typically seen wielding high-voltage Shock Batons.

Nexus Engineers: These units function as the Nexus Core's elite shock troopers, surpassing the AAHW's ATP Engineers in overall combat effectiveness. They are armed with powerful shotguns and wear a modified mask similar to their AAHW counterparts, distinguished by a vibrant red visor instead of yellow, and a prominent crest running across the middle. Their uniform includes a striking red beret and a chest-protecting plate of armor atop a red agency suit, contrasting with the AAHW Engineer's standard suit. Notably, they bleed red blood, unlike their AAHW counterparts, suggesting a different biological or cybernetic composition.

Nexus Soldats: Representing the absolute pinnacle of the Nexus Core's elite ground forces, Soldats historically served as Director Phobos's personal guard. Their unique combat signature is the consistent dual-wielding of weaponry, typically preferring brutal melee implements akin to the Merczerkers. However, Soldats dual-wielding firearms can also be encountered, making them unpredictable and devastating. Like the Nexus Engineers, their eyepiece lenses glow bright red, and they wear berets, dark grey balaclavas, earpieces, body armor, and shoulder pads. They also bleed red blood, further distinguishing them from AAHW equivalents.

This list accounts for only a fraction of their complete military might. The Nexus Core also deploys genetically and cybernetically enhanced super-soldiers, the aforementioned G0L3Ms, a range of terrifying failed experiments, and various autonomous combat robots.

4.name: Nevada Central
4.content:
Nevada Central is a sprawling urban center situated on the eastern coastline of Nevada, existing in considerable isolation from Nexus City. This metropolitan area is defined by its extreme privatization, saturated with corporate entities and exhibiting minimal discernible government influence, operating under a system strongly resembling, if not identical to, anarcho-capitalism.

The official government or any overt ruling authority within Nevada Central remains conspicuously absent. In stark contrast to Nexus City, Nevada Central champions a radically more libertarian and privatized urban model. The sole semblance of a police or authoritative presence is the private security force, PrivSec. This vacuum of traditional law enforcement has inadvertently created fertile ground for criminal syndicates, allowing them to operate with brazen public visibility. Concurrently, the city has become a clandestine haven for the establishment and hideouts of various Private Military Firms. Despite its highly privatized nature, Nevada Central still maintains essential public services, including extensive public transportation networks and organized traffic systems.

Nevada Central is populated by a diverse civilian populace engaged in a wide array of occupations. The city heavily integrates G03LMs into its workforce, employing them for a multitude of tasks. Notable examples of their ubiquitous presence include their roles as formidable bouncers and guards at the notorious Slaughter Time studio and the bustling Club Advent.

The city is also a nexus for several infamous criminal organizations, collectively known as The Toughs, VendeVice Syndicate, and the Vampires.

5.name: The Toughs
5.content:
The Toughs are a notorious biker gang of street thugs who exert a significant presence across the gritty streets of Nevada Central. Their operations are fiercely overseen by the unusually short and enigmatic Sweet Tony, their uncontested leader. The gang's distinctive aesthetic draws heavily from the greaser subculture of the 1950s and 60s, evident in their signature pompadour hairstyles, rugged leather jackets, and ever-present sunglasses. Their profound fondness for motorcycles is, of course, central to their identity. A hallmark of their gang's uniform, distinguishing them plainly from other factions, are the bright pink, triangular shades worn by most Toughs members.

The Toughs Units:

Toughs (Standard Members): These are the most common and numerous members of the gang, hailing from all walks of life within Nevada Central. They are typically armed with basic, improvised weaponry, ranging from heavy-duty baseball bats and sharpened bike chains to the occasional small sidearm acquired through illicit means. They form the backbone of the Toughs' street presence and general enforcer operations.

Night Toughs: A specialized and more formidable contingent, the Night Toughs are wholly dedicated to the relentless hunting of Vampires throughout the city. While sharing the fundamental aggressive disposition of their standard counterparts, Night Toughs are noticeably tougher and more strategically equipped. They distinguish themselves visually with unique, ramshackle armor pieced together from various salvaged materials and a grim shroud draped over their faces, obscuring their features. Crucially, their armaments are specifically chosen to exploit the inherent weaknesses of Vampires, including crude but effective torches, sharpened wooden stakes, and custom-built crossbows loaded with specialized bolts.

6.name: G03LM
6.content:
The G03LM (an acronym for Generation-03, Limited Model) units are a line of mass-produced butler-class combat automatons, serving as a primary asset provided and deployed by the Nexus Core. Their designation, "G03LM," is a deliberate linguistic play on the mythological "golem"—a creature typically fashioned from clay and brought to life as a servant—a fitting reference given their synthesized origins and programmed subservience.

Standing approximately 1.35 times the height of an average human, G03LMs possess formidable corporeal strength, allowing them to wield exceptionally heavy weaponry with effortless ease. This includes oversized, G03LM-scaled submachine guns and devastatingly powerful giant mallets. Physically, they exhibit a slightly pale, almost pasty skin tone, with their entire head and body visibly crisscrossed by extensive stitching and grotesque scars, strongly evoking the eerie aesthetic of Frankenstein's Monster—a chilling nod to their manufactured existence. Their most striking and unsettling facial features are a perpetually gaping mouth revealing rows of sickly yellow teeth, and a circulatory system that pumps a distinct, unnervingly orange blood.

Despite their monstrous appearance and status as some of Nevada's most vicious and feared combatants, G03LMs exhibit a startling behavioral paradox: their dialogue, particularly when addressing perceived allies, is surprisingly polite and almost formal. This ingrained decorum stems from their primary design by the Nexus Core as butler units, a role that apparently required meticulous training in manners. When engaged in combat, G03LMs frequently issue polite yet firm commands for their adversaries to "stand down" or "submit." Should they come under attack, they might calmly remark on the futility of such aggression, advising the attacker to "refrain from that action." When delivering unique spoken lines, their dialogue often revolves around matters of spatial violation, typically stating something akin to, "Oh. You have seemed to have wandered the wrong way." This ingrained butler personality, however, never compromises their innate bloodlust or their unparalleled combat skills, making them truly unpredictable and terrifying adversaries.

Intriguingly, there is anecdotal evidence suggesting that G03LMs, despite their artificial nature, may possess rudimentary or evolving emotional capacities.

7.name: The Vampires
7.content:
The Vampires are a notorious gang that perpetuates the terrifying myth of classic night creatures prowling the city, stalking unsuspecting victims, ambushing them, and feasting on their blood. Or so the street whispers claim. In stark reality, the "Vampires" are a flamboyant poser gang, distinguished by their extensive body modifications and grotesque dental implants designed to mimic the fangs of traditional nocturnal predators. They are fiercely led by the equally theatrical Count Dragula, himself a supreme poser of the highest order. Every member sports these artificial fangs, complemented by ramshackle, patchwork leather armor that epitomizes their aggressive gothic punk aesthetic. A signature piece of their attire is the pair of LED goggles, their screens constantly displaying chaotic, randomly scrolling text.

In combat, Vampires exhibit astonishing resilience, capable of shrugging off wounds that would be instantly fatal to lesser adversaries, often appearing to rise from the dead after receiving what seems like a killing blow. However, their unnerving durability is not without critical vulnerabilities. They are acutely susceptible to fire, which bypasses their regenerative capabilities. Furthermore, proper executions or particularly gore-inducing finishing moves irrevocably end their existence. Upon suffering a definitive death, a Vampire's body will gruesomely ignite, erupting into a writhing, self-immolating fireball.

Vampire Units:
The Vampires utilize two primary types of combatants within their ranks, each with distinct fighting styles:

Vampire Punks: These are the most common and agile members of the gang. Visually identifiable by their vibrant yellow accents and an array of punk-inspired gothic hairstyles, Vampire Punks engage targets up close with savage claw swipes. From a distance, they launch themselves in sudden, predatory leaps, attempting to grapple victims and tear into them with their fangs. Despite their remarkable durability in battle, Vampire Punks are astonishingly nimble, capable of quick dodges and rapid recovery from being staggered. When operating in groups, they employ coordinated tactics, encircling their prey to assault them from multiple, relentless angles, making escape incredibly difficult.

Vampire Bruisers: These formidable variants are noticeably larger and more muscular than their punk brethren, typically bald and adorned with striking magenta accents on their armor. While slower in general movement than the common Vampire Punks, Bruisers possess a surprising burst of speed, enabling them to lunge forward suddenly to grab a victim and deliver a brutal bite. They are also capable of initiating devastating charge attacks, ramming into enemies with bone-shattering velocity. Despite their imposing size, Bruisers maintain a surprising level of agility, allowing them to maneuver effectively in close quarters. Crucially, they are every bit as durable, if not more so, than their smaller, more agile punk counterparts, making them exceptionally tough to put down.

8.name: The VendeVice Syndicate
8.content:
The VendeVice Syndicate is a powerful and affluent criminal organization operating within Nevada Central, meticulously controlled by the formidable Don Vendel Vice. This well-established mafia holds significant sway and boasts ownership of numerous prominent properties throughout the downtown district. Among their most notable assets are a seemingly legitimate restaurant, which surreptitiously functions as a front for the sophisticated smuggling of contraband into the city, and the immensely popular nightclub, Club Advent, which serves as a major hub for their illicit activities.

VendeVice Syndicate Units:
The Syndicate's enforcers are organized into a clear hierarchy, each with distinct roles and capabilities:

Toadies: These individuals represent the primary tier of henchmen within the VendeVice Syndicate. Easily identified by their classic pinstriped suits and fedora hats, Toadies are notably tougher and more capable than generic street thugs like The Toughs. They employ fundamental group tactics, such as maintaining cover and executing flanking maneuvers. Traditionally, their arsenal consists of reliable revolvers and hard-hitting shotguns, making them effective close-to-medium range combatants.

Button Men: Holding a significantly higher rank in the VendeVice hierarchy, the Button Men are hardened, elite enforcers. They are instantly recognizable by their immaculate white suits and signature sunglasses. Wielding formidable tommy guns equipped with extended drum magazines, Button Men are notorious for their highly effective, lethal spray of bullets, capable of neutralizing targets with overwhelming suppression and damage.

9.name: S-3LF
9.content:
S-3LF is a profound conceptual construct, representing an individual's intrinsic soul, their unique identity, the sum of their thoughts, and the totality of their lived experiences. It is not a tangible, physical entity, but rather an ethereal yet fundamental aspect of being. Furthermore, S-3LF embodies an individual's inherent potential for growth, their capacity for learning, and their ability to forge strength through a myriad of experiences. Consequently, entities with severely limited or entirely absent free will—such as the "programmed" operatives of the A.A.H.W.—possess minimal to nonexistent S-3LFs.

The potent S-3LF energy boasts a wide array of practical applications. The Nexus Core, in particular, has mastered its harnessing, utilizing it as a foundational energy source to power its vast factories, illuminate entire cities, and fuel a myriad of other industrial and technological requirements throughout Nevada.

In advanced bio-engineering, specialized Vessels can be employed to contain and house S-3LF. This remarkable capability essentially allows the transfer of a complete consciousness into a pre-engineered, cloned shell. This intricate and transformative process is known as Enmeshment. More broadly defined, Enmeshment refers to any process or series of processes that result in the profound and often irreversible binding or integration of disparate entities.

10.name: Project Nexus
10.content:
Project Nexus is a highly secretive and ambitious scientific program, conceived with the ultimate goal of mass-producing soldiers within the harsh landscape of Nevada. Established approximately 30 years prior to the present narrative, it flourished for 15 years under the direct leadership of Director Phobos until his eventual demise. The project's initial operations were nearly brought to ruin by a devastating insurrection. During this tumultuous period, the chief scientist, Dr. Christoff, played an undeniably pivotal, albeit controversial, role in both the program's foundational success and the subsequent catastrophic outbreak.

The vast majority of Project Nexus's groundbreaking, and often horrifying, research was conducted within the immense Science Tower. Despite Dr. Christoff's best efforts to dismantle the program from within, a significant number of scientists loyal to the original vision survived the insurrection. These staunch loyalists eventually regrouped and successfully restarted the project under a new, unified banner: the Nexus Core.

At a critical juncture, utterly repulsed by the monstrous applications of his scientific endeavors, Dr. Christoff initiated a calculated act of sabotage. He deliberately unleashed the project's various experiments, including hordes of grotesque Zombies and terrifying Abominations, from their confinement. These unleashed horrors immediately began indiscriminately attacking both scientists and soldiers, including Nexus agents. However, this widespread chaos was merely a diversion. Christoff himself rose up, launching a brutal, one-man war against his former comrades. It was during this period of intense conflict that Dr. Christoff shed his old identity, fully embracing the persona of Jesus, now augmented by a formidable Halo which he had audaciously stolen directly from the project's hidden vaults.

While its charter was never entirely explicit, the Project Nexus's original foundational purpose was ostensibly noble: to significantly improve the quality of life for Nevadans through the innovative utilization of S-3LF technology and cloning advancements. Early, ethically dubious projects within the organization included:

Dr. Christoff's 'Sleepwalker' Project: Designed to allow Nevadans to re-experience the synthesized memories of cloned individuals, purportedly as a revolutionary form of instant education.
Dr. Crackpot's 'Project Zed': A perilous and ultimately disastrous endeavor aimed at resurrecting the deceased, with catastrophic, unforeseen consequences.
Dr. Hoffnar's Study of Dissonant Energy: A deep dive into the enigmatic and dangerous energies emanating from "The Other Place."
Tragically, these potentially beneficial, if unsettling, scientific pursuits were systematically perverted by Director Phobos. Driven by insatiable ambition and a thirst for power, Phobos dramatically repurposed the project's resources. He began illicitly selling clones as disposable servants and expendable soldiers to generate vast funds. His ultimate obsession became the pursuit of immortality through Project Gestalt, an audacious initiative designed to trap and consolidate numerous S-3LFs into one colossal MAG, which Phobos intended to fully control and inhabit. This morally bankrupt redirection of Project Nexus eventually paved the way for the horrific proliferation of undead creations, including relentless Zombies, psychologically traumatized Sleepwalker patients, and grotesque Abominations.

Fifteen years after the initial, devastating outbreak triggered by Dr. Christoff's betrayal, Project Nexus remains alarmingly active. The intervening years have seen a purported perfection, or near-perfection, of the cloning process. This refined technology has since been leveraged for the mass-production of countless Nexus units, forming the core of the resurgent military faction. The loyalist scientists, who weathered the initial storm, successfully reformed and solidified their power base as the Nexus Core. For reasons of operational redundancy and strategic segmentation, the Nexus Core has reportedly split into two distinct, interconnected groups, ensuring the project's continued, relentless pursuit of Phobos's warped vision.

This article contains content from the EvaGeeks.org Wiki article Shinji Ikari. Please view that page's revision history for the list of authors.
This article has a collection of images to further represent its content. To see its gallery, visit Shinji Ikari/Gallery.

Shinji Ikari (碇シンジ, Ikari Shinji?)[2] is the Third Child, the main protagonist of the Neon Genesis Evangelion franchise, and the designated pilot of Evangelion Unit-01. He is the son of Gehirn bioengineer Yui Ikari and NERV Commander (formerly Chief of Gehirn) Gendo Ikari. After his mother's death, he was abandoned by his father and lived for 11 years with his sensei, until he was summoned to Tokyo-3 to pilot Unit-01 against the Angels. He lives initially just with Misato Katsuragi; they are later joined by Asuka Langley Soryu.

Appearance

Shinji has medium-length straight brown hair and grey-blue eyes. Shinji is also very skinny, and often has his shirt tucked in, showing that he is a rather tidy person. When spending time at NERV or out in the city, he wears his uniform which is a white dress shirt, blue t-shirt, dark pants and white sneakers, though when in his apartment, he will often wear something more casual. Shinji's plug suit has a very light blue torso, complemented by the rest being a dark blue color with black portions as well.

Personality

Shinji initially shows a passive and laid-back personality, inheriting such traits from his relaxed life with his sensei. When he is told to pilot Unit-01, he denies, not wanting to do it. Though Shinji denies it, he yearns for praise, and he eventually begins to pilot Unit-01 to gain the approval and love from his father. He also continually tells himself "I mustn't run away!",[3] further demonstrating his need to move forward and let go of the past.

Shinji shows a great fear of emotional pain and of being hated or left behind, likely due to his perception of being abandoned in his youth and, subsequently, blaming himself for not being good enough to make his father stick around. In general, Shinji is shown to be introverted and disconnected from physical reality due to having little to no meaningful contact with others. In social party situations, he is shown to be quite uncomfortable, and he often has difficulty controlling his emotions around others due to his hard time letting go of the past. He is shown to the extreme of this, forsaking many lives (even his own) to save one person.

Due to Shinji's high nostalgia and fragile emotional state, he chooses to shut out the world, as evidenced by the headphones he wears rather often, plugged into an SDAT music player.[4] Through all this, Shinji is also aware of his own faults, has a detailed memory of the past, and generally is outwardly gentle. He is the only one who tries to find a reason to fight the Angels, and sometimes his justification for fleeing from piloting is to avoid hurting others.
Relationships

Gendo Ikari

Shinji ID (Rebuild)
Torn-up letter from Gendo.
Gendo abandoned Shinji shortly after Yui disappeared into Unit-01, sending him to live with his sensei. Shinji resents Gendo for this, despite having run away from Gendo the last time they spoke, three years before, the last time they visited Yui's grave.[5] In Episode 01, Shinji shows Misato the letter his father sent, summoning him to Tokyo-3. The entirety of the letter is blanked out, except for the handwritten words, "Come. — Gendo Ikari".

Nonetheless, Shinji still longs for words of praise from Gendo.[6] He never understood his father's motives (neither did anyone else, except perhaps Fuyutsuki) until the very end of the series—at the same time as Gendo realizes Yui's. Gendo, in Episode 21, resembles Shinji even more strongly and reveals he is used to being hated and alone. He can be seen as a kind of negative adult mirror of Shinji, in contrast to Kaji, as Gendo reveals in End of Evangelion that he resents not being able to connect with Shinji and was afraid of hurting him, so he chose to shut himself away from Shinji, as he believed that when he was close to Shinji he only hurt him, so Gendo thought it was better to do nothing at all, just like Shinji shut himself away from other people, as Gendo believed he wasn't worthy of love. He apologizes to Shinji as he accepts his "punishment".

Misato Katsuragi

After moving to Tokyo-3, Shinji lives with Misato in her small apartment with her pet penguin Pen Pen. He disapproves of her lifestyle of beer, snacks, and instant meals. He also shows an obvious fright toward Misato's perceived attraction to him. However, Misato shows that she has deep respect and regard for Shinji, breaking to tears after she thought he was lost to the Angel Leliel.

Despite a rocky start, Shinji's relationship with Misato becomes one of his strongest connections. Though they are slow to admit it, they understand each other well due to each being aware of the insecurities of the other. Their interpersonal problems stem from their fear of losing those they love, and though Misato tries to help Shinji understand that life involves both joy and pain, she herself struggles with the same fear. Shinji's fraught relationship with his father mirrors Misato's with her own, and each understands the feelings of abandonment and isolation that plague them, albeit with differing outcomes. When Toji and Kensuke point out that Misato allows Shinji to see that side of her because she considers him family, their connection becomes even stronger. He is comfortable enough around her to answer Kaji's prying questions about her personal life without embarrassment. He often comically scoffs at Toji and Kensuke's infatuation with Misato. Misato, however, has difficulty in reaching out to Shinji in later episodes[7] and Shinji is horrified when she offers her body to him, seeing her as a mother figure.

ShinjiMisatoEp16
Shinji's joy at being praised by Misato
As his "boss"/NERV Chief Tactical Officer, Misato can be quite intense, causing Shinji to not come home at night more than once, though they always reconcile. Shinji comes to admire Misato's resolve in combat situations—something which often serves to fuel his own dire confidence, leading him to disobey her orders on certain occasions. He compares her calm yet bossy demeanor when they first meet Asuka to Ritsuko's own stoicism. Shinji, for much of the earlier parts of the story, wants Misato to always praise him, and while she is quick to do so when Shinji shows prowess and courage, she also criticizes him when he acts recklessly and goes against orders. Initially, this frustrates Shinji, but it is through Misato's prodding over the length of the series that Shinji comes to realize why he pilots the Eva, as she has much influence in helping him develop a greater sense of responsibility and maturity. Losing Misato in The End of Evangelion and in the manga devastates him. In the manga adaptation, it is unclear how much of the story Shinji remembers (if any at all) after he rejects Instrumentality, but in the very last panel, he is shown going off confidently into the future with Misato's cross pendant (which she gave to him just before she died saving him) tied to his suitcase.

Asuka Langley Sohryu

Main article: Shinji and Asuka's Relationship
Shinji is attracted to Asuka, though the reasoning is not explicitly stated. It might be that her bullying sometimes causes Shinji to bite back at her, as Asuka wants his attention, and he views Asuka, in a strange fashion, as a source of strength, one that he misses when Asuka is laid low by her encounter with Arael. However, Shinji directly expresses his feelings for Asuka by trying to kiss her as she sleeps,[8] when he masturbated at the accidental exposure of the then-comatose girl's breasts,[9] and in the Episode 26 Instrumentality sequence when he says "I want to help you somehow and be with you forever.", and Asuka states she wants Shinji all to herself and that she is not only aware of his masturbation at the hospital, but also implies that it is, in fact, a habit of his.[10][11] In Episode 22, Asuka laments that Shinji "won't do anything, won't help me, won't even hold me.",[12] revealing Asuka's frustrations at Shinji not picking up on her advances, particularly earlier in Episode 9 and their kiss in Episode 15, despite him barely understanding them.[13] Asuka also seems very jealous of Shinji's interactions with Rei, which furthers her antipathy at her. Asuka hates passivity, as this reminds her of dolls and her past trauma with her mother. It is also why she takes a dislike to Rei.[14]

Both of You, Dance Like You Want to Win!
Asuka and Shinji listening to music in Episode 09.
This is also paired with Asuka eventually letting go of seeking Kaji to validate her as an adult, as she starts to begrudgingly accept Shinji's piloting prowess and to find an equal in him, something she is unwilling to do with Rei. After Episode 16 however when Shinji surpasses her synch scores, she starts resenting his success as in her view, Shinji hasn't worked for it whereas Asuka spent her whole life training for piloting Eva and she is unsure of how to deal with not being the best. Asuka's expectations for Shinji as a strong male, that she used to project on Kaji, clash with the reality of him as a "housebroken male", despite him being much more than that: Asuka believes Shinji is unwilling to help her, in combat or otherwise, despite him showing bravery even without request - like when he rescued her from the volcano in Episode 10. Additionally, Asuka interprets Shinji's inaction during their kiss in Episode 15 not as lack of understanding, fear or insecurity, but as conscious rejection, which she greatly resents.[15][16][17]

Despite Asuka's own abrasiveness toward Shinji, she develops a rather skewed mentorship with him. It is her constant battling, coupled with her seemingly unquenchable energy, that often gives Shinji strength and confidence he didn't know he had. During the days that they lived in a furnished room at NERV HQ practicing their dance routine, Shinji began to understand where Asuka was coming from and allowed himself to confide a little in her. In the end, it was her perfectionism which awakened Shinji's confidence, allowing them to synchronize and defeat Israfel. Asuka's ambivalence regarding their mutual feelings often confuses Shinji, leaving him unsure as to what he feels for her, as Asuka, in order to avoid intimacy forming between them, sometimes reverts to her self-defense mechanisms, and pushes Shinji away, even if Shinji seems barely affected by those, as per his passive nature he seems content to merely have her attention.

Her frustration with Shinji often leads to her recounting her own insecurities to him, much to her surprise. Their occasional public bickering often comically leads to annoyance on the part of the NERV staff—particularly Fuyutsuki, who feels that they are constantly embarrassing the organization, and Misato, who has to live with them. Due to this constant bickering, their classmates often tease them by referring to them as "newlyweds", which results in them blushing and getting embarrassed. These instances give subtle clues that their friends and others around them see a relationship between them that even Shinji and Asuka aren't yet aware of.

Asuka forms less of a connection to Shinji in the manga but they still show interest in each other. They meet under slightly different circumstances, as Asuka has already defeated Gaghiel by herself. Her more childish personality turns Shinji off at first, but they quickly grow closer. They almost kiss in an elevator, but are interrupted by Misato and Kaji. Shinji demonstrates feelings for Asuka in the manga's hospital scene, and states he wants to protect her. Unlike in EoE, they fight together against the MP Evas, and they do not kill her. They meet again in the ending of the manga, when Asuka is stuck in a crowd and Shinji pulls her hand, and they seem to have a faint memory of each other and some sort of lingering feelings. Sadamoto conceived their dance training in the manga as akin to a "kiss", underlining his psychological connection "to a girl he loves", in place of kiss scene in Episode 15. Asuka would be Shinji's symbol for his longing for the opposite sex, differently from Rei's "motherly" existence.[18] Asuka is present as his childhood friend in the alternative world in Episode 26 and Rei seems to think they are an item. In contrast to the simple "favourable feelings" Shinji has with most other characters, Evangelion Chronicle describes their relationship as "complex feelings" and "love and hate.[19][20][21]

AsukaShinjiSexEoE
Shinji with Asuka on top of him in The End of Evangelion.
In The End of Evangelion, Shinji spends much of the film seeking Asuka and has multiple fantasies and exchanges with her, including of a clear sexual nature. Shinji says he is just like her, but Asuka says Shinji can't understand her. Shinji replies that Asuka never tells him anything, and thus it is impossible to do so. He is certain nobody cares about him. Asuka comments on his masturbation earlier in the hospital, and implies it is in fact a habit of his. Asuka gives him an ultimatum, demanding him give herself to her, but Shinji is unwilling to give back any affection himself, much like Asuka herself is, and believes nobody is nice to him, which Asuka and other characters disagree, but Shinji doesn't believe it. Shinji desperately asks for Asuka's affection and even proclaims he wants to be with her forever, but Asuka refuses, as she is unwilling to serve as just an emotional crutch and escape to him. This causes him to lash out at her, and he begins choking Asuka. However, Asuka is the second person to come back after he rejects Instrumentality, and Shinji finds her laying by his side. Shinji starts choking her again, to feel the existence of an Other, of the person he had hoped to meet again,[22][23] but instead of reacting with aggression or hostility, Asuka caresses Shinji gently (similarly to how Yui had done a few minutes earlier in the film) which stops him as this first open act of compassion demonstrates to Shinji that he might be accepted after all.[24][25][26][27] According to staff commentary, Asuka "gently" (as noted by the storyboard) moved her hand to confirm Shinji's presence herself.[28] Overwhelmed, Shinji begins to cry. It is left open where their relationship will go from there. Hideaki Anno has also written a song about their relationship, which was fully produced and recorded, but ultimately unused, in favor of Komm, süsser Tod.

Rei Ayanami

Shinji first encounters Rei at the Nerv HQ in Episode 1, after being summoned by his father regarding the oncoming Angel attack. Despite being heavily injured, Rei insists on piloting the Eva when Shinji protests against getting in the robot, eventually forcing him to face his responsibility. She is shown as a practical and mysterious figure, acting solely on commands and refusing all social contact. Shinji is initially puzzled at Rei's behaviour, and the bond she seems to have with Gendo, in contrast to Shinji's own and much more strained relationship with his father. Through his persistent efforts to befriend Rei however, she ends up opening up somewhat to him and realizing more about herself and her role in the Human Instrumentality Project.[19]

ReiShinjiEp16
Rei getting visibly flustered at Shinji saying she'd "make a good mother"
The extent of Shinji's attraction to Rei is unclear even to him; certainly, it is of a different sort than his sexual and seemingly romantic attraction to Asuka. It is implied that he is drawn to the vestiges of his mother that lie within Rei. As they grow closer, their relationship is a source of both joy and pain for both of them. It should be noted though, due to being genetically related to Rei's ultimate fate, the two may never have a romantic relationship, or even wish for one. Rei also seems to associate Shinji with Gendo with some level, implying she might also feel a form of familial connection with him.[29] Shinji relates to Rei's sense of isolation and loneliness; it is not until Shinji is absent that Rei begins to understand that she was in fact feeling these things. She comes to realize that she wants to protect him, and in the battle with Armisael, she self-destructs to save Shinji. After Rei comes back as another clone, Shinji becomes alienated from her, however, in End of Evangelion she decides to hand control of Instrumentality to Shinji instead of Gendo, and gives him the choice to accept or reject it. She is last seen in her Quantum form briefly watching Shinji just before he notices Asuka on the beach.[30] Anno has described Rei as Shinji's unconscious self.[31]

Rei has a much stronger bond to Shinji in the manga and their relationship has far more development, as Rei is greatly impacted by touching Shinji's hands and as Armisael attacks her, she realizes she has feelings for him she cannot understand. She also realizes she is jealous of Asuka dividing Shinji's attention. However, she is absent from the ending. While Asuka was as a symbol of "heterosexual desire", Sadamoto designed Rei as a "mother figure",[32][33] thinking of her as "the Yin opposed to Asuka".[34] As such, he decided to give Rei more room in the manga, emphasizing Rei's maternal role.[35][36] Perhaps alluding to them having a sibling relationship instead of a romantic one, official material states Gendo intended for his biological daughter to be named Rei had Shinji not been born a boy.[37]

Ryoji Kaji

KajiShinjiEp19
Kaji convicing Shinji to pilot again in Episode 19
Shinji looks up to Kaji as a sort of mentor, and accepts behavior in him that he would disapprove of in other characters. For instance, in Episode 08 when Kaji asks him about Misato's sleeping habits, implying that Shinji and Misato might be in a sexual relationship and simultaneously implying that he is intimately familiar with these habits as well, Shinji just laughs rather than being overwhelmed with embarrassment. After the Israfel fiasco, it was Kaji who came up with the idea of the dance routine to help Shinji and Asuka synchronize with each other. His relationship with Misato is constantly paralleled with Shinji's own relationship with Asuka, A common interpretation is to see Kaji as Shinji's positive adult role model, with Gendo as a more negative model.[38] Similarly, Misato and Ritsuko are mirrors for Asuka, as are their respective relationships.[39] Kaji gives advice to Shinji multiple times on many matters though Shinji has difficulty understanding him, as Kaji has his own insecurities. He motivates Shinji to pilot again in Episode 19.

Shinji is next seen visiting his mother's grave with Gendo, who reveals that there is nobody there, nor does he have any pictures of Yui. Though Shinji attempts to make a connection with Gendo, the latter dismisses him completely. Shinji returns home and begins playing the cello, with which Asuka notes he has great talent.[72] He says he started playing at age five, and still plays now and again because, "No one told [him] to stop." She then says she's bored and wants to practice kissing and though Shinji is nervous, they share a kiss, though Asuka is upset by his lack of emotion

2.content:
AFFILIATION(S)
NERV
RANK/TITLE
First Child
AGE
18 (born 30 March 2001)
KNOWN RELATIVES
Yui Ikari (Derivative)
Shinji Ikari (Blood Relative)

Rei Ayanami (綾波 レイあやなみ れい/アヤナミ レイ), Ayanami Rei?) is a fictional character from the Neon Genesis Evangelion franchise. She is the First Child (referred as the First Children in the Japanese version), the pilot of Evangelion Unit-00 and one of the central characters.

At the beginning of the series, little is known about Rei, and her stoic personality puzzles her peers. As the series progresses, her personality evolves, and she becomes more involved with the people around her, particularly her classmate and fellow Eva pilot Shinji Ikari. In the concluding events of the storyline, the audience learns that Rei's mysterious origins tie into the story's resolution where its revealed that she is a clone of Shinji's mother Yui Ikari. Her role in this conclusion is not made clear in the TV series, but is one of the principal plot points of The End of Evangelion.

Appearance

Rei is a teenage girl with a slender build and pale skin. She has short pale blue hair with bangs centered to the middle and has red eyes. At the beginning of the series, she would wear bandages such as her arm and her eye one. She wears the same school uniform but wears white loafers instead, and black ankle socks.
Profile

Rei Ayanami OP
Rei Ayanami in the anime opening
No specific information is given about Rei's origin or heritage. Ritsuko Akagi states that Rei was born in a certain room deep in the lower levels of NERV headquarters, but this is all that is explicitly revealed in the series about her creation.[1] The Red Cross Book stated that Rei was created from the "salvaged remains" of Yui Ikari after Yui's absorption into Unit-01 in 2004. The connection between Rei and Yui is implied a few times during the series. Gendo introduces Rei to the NERV staff in 2010 as an "acquaintance's child" whom he is temporarily taking care of. In episode 21, Naoko Akagi says that Rei physically resembles Yui. The character model used in the 2010 scenes is based on development materials in which her age is only 4.

Rei Ayanami Inside Eva
Rei inside Unit-00 Entry plug
Kaworu Nagisa cryptically mentions in their only conversation that she is "the same" as him.[2] This statement was expanded in the director's cut of the episode, in which Kaworu goes on to say that he and Rei are human vessels for the souls of Adam and Lilith, respectively. Later in the episode, she generates an external A.T. Field which is as strong as Kaworu's. In a pseudo-hallucinatory scene in episode 25, Gendo tells Rei that the day of Third Impact is the day for which she was created. In The End of Evangelion, she plays an important role in the Third Impact, although not in the fashion that was intended by Gendo.

Rei is shown spending unknown lengths of time in an LCL-filled tube underneath a structure resembling a giant brain in the Dummy System room, the reasons for which are not revealed. The circular wall of this room is originally depicted as being covered with DNA sequences, but near the end of the series, it is revealed to be an LCL-filled tank in which dozens of soulless clones of Rei are held. The clones are said by Ritsuko to be the cores of the dummy plugs; she also refers to them as "spare parts" and later as "vessels" for Rei. The movie pamphlet and volume 11 of the manga state that she can be replaced entirely, with her soul being transferred to a new clone body every time she dies, although her memory becomes muddled with each transfer. Other supporting evidence in the anime includes her earlier line that "if I die, I can be replaced."

Rei I
Rei I, being introduced to Gehirn personnel by Gendo.
While they are the same character, these different incarnations are commonly referred to as "Rei I," "Rei II," and "Rei III," after episodes and musical pieces with the same names, and are denoted as such in the storyboards and script as well.[3] In episode 23, the controller that Ritsuko uses to destroy the clones lists numbered clones from "Rei 004" and upwards. Rei I was the very first incarnation and was murdered by Naoko Akagi in 2010 (as shown in Episode 21). Rei II is introduced in the first episode and appears in the most episodes of the incarnations. She dies when she sacrifices herself and Unit-00 to destroy Armisael in episode 23. Rei III is seen from the second half of episode 23 through to The End of Evangelion.

In the final episode of Neon Genesis Evangelion, the audience is introduced to a pseudo-hallucinatory alternate reality. Here Rei's personality is completely different, and her behavior is more "normal" (for example, she shows embarrassment and anger when she thinks Shinji looked up her skirt, in stark contrast to her emotionless reaction to the incident with Shinji in Episode 05). The Evangelion spin-off manga Neon Genesis Evangelion: Angelic Days is set in this alternate universe, and its version of Rei is a central character.

In The End of Evangelion, a shining figure of Rei is shown for a few frames looking down at Misato and Ritsuko moments before they die. These spectral images also appear over the corpses of the slain NERV personnel. During Third Impact, multiple Reis appear in the NERV control room, seemingly apparitions created by Lilith. She also briefly watches over Shinji and Asuka in the final scene of the movie.[4]
ADVERTISEMENT

Personality

"Whatever else, she needs to be painted in as a bitterly unhappy young girl with little sense of presence." Hideaki Anno, to Yoshiyuki Sadamoto on Rei's character design[5]

At the start of the series, Rei is socially withdrawn, seemingly emotionless, and rarely interacts with anyone, except for Gendo, to whom she initially displays loyalty but with whom she has a generally distant relationship. She lives by herself in a dull sparsely-furnished apartment in Tokyo-3. Toward the end of the series, Shinji comments that her apartment is very similar to the place where Ritsuko says Rei was born.[6] Rei is also shown to have an interest in psychology and genetics, including reading a book in German on the latter subject in Episode 09.[7]

"An emotional change causes certain muscles in the face to tense, producing an "expression". Rei is expressionless but is it that she doesn't feel emotion, or that she is merely unable to express it?" Yoshiyuki Sadamoto on Rei [emphasis in original].

Rei smile
Rei's first smile.
As the series progresses, she begins to develop relationships with others and to show moments of genuine emotion, to even become sad and cry. Her English voice actor, Amanda Winn-Lee describes her saying, '"Rei is not totally devoid of personality, otherwise she would not be interesting." There is a small spark of humanity, but it is "clouded by this huge sense of negative self-worth and the realization that she is expendable." The joy of playing Rei is exploring that small spark.'[11] And also said: "I got into a weird mode - I can't describe it. It's a good thing I'm in a little padded room when I'm doing it because that's where she belongs. She knows she's expendable, but the thing is, she's still human so you can't do her totally catatonic."
